{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}} {{Infobox person |name = Hugh Falkus |image = Hugh Falkus 3.jpg |caption = |birth_date = {{Birth date|1917|05|15|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Cheam]], [[Surrey]], England |death_date = {{Death date and age|1996|03|30|1917|05|15|df=yes}} |death_place = Birkby, [[Ravenglass]], [[Eskdale, Cumbria|Eskdale]], [[Cumbria]], England |other_names = Hugh Edward Lance Falkus |known_for = Writer, film maker, television presenter, pilot and angler |occupation = |nationality = United Kingdom }} '''Hugh Falkus''' (15 May 1917 – 30 March 1996) was a British [[writer]], filmmaker and presenter, [[World War II]] [[aviator|pilot]] and [[angling|angler]]. In an extremely varied career, he is perhaps best known for his seminal books on [[angling]], particularly [[salmon]] and [[sea trout]] fishing; however, he was also a noted filmmaker and broadcaster for the [[BBC]].
==Biography==
Hugh Edward Lance Falkus was born to James Falkus, a [[Surrey]] bank manager, and his wife Alice Maud. James retired early to a boat, first on the [[Essex]] marshes and then in [[Devon]], upon which Hugh was sent to the [[Culford School|East Anglian School]], in [[Suffolk]]. According to his entry in the [[Dictionary of National Biography|Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]], Hugh caught his first fish when he was four, learned to shoot when he was six, and was an expert helmsman by the age of fifteen. By eighteen he had learned to fly, and at twenty he became a pilot in the [[RAF]].
On 11 July 1939 he married Doris Marjorie Walter, and they had two sets of twins (three sons and a daughter). The youngest son, Anthony, born in 1952, died in infancy. The older twins, Christopher and Malcolm, born in 1940, had successful careers, Christopher becoming a prominent publisher while Malcolm's career has been in economic history. Falkus' only daughter, Rowena Mary, is a Benedictine nun.
In June 1940 Falkus' [[Supermarine Spitfire|Spitfire]] was shot down over [[France]]<ref name=Indie>{{cite web|last1=Burnett|first1=David|title=Hugh Falkus: Obituary|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/hugh-falkus-obituary-1302872.html|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=14 July 2015|date=2 April 1996}}</ref> and he spent the rest of the [[Second World War|war]] in German prison camps, including [[Stalag Luft III]] the [[Stalag Luft III escape|Great Escape]] camp. After the war he left Doris and in 1950 he married Diana Vaughan, the young editor of ''Argosy'' magazine, but on 12 May 1951 Diana was drowned, along with Charles Osborne, Bill Brendon and Sam Lee, in a boating accident off the coast of [[Achill Island]] in [[County Mayo]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], while they were making a film about the local shark hunting industry. Filming near the Daisy Rocks, a huge wave estimated to be 27 feet high capsized and sank the lifeboat being used for the filming. Falkus, a powerful swimmer, took command and ensure other members of the party including his wife were equipped with flotation devices; roping them together into a raft, and then set out for help. He collapsed unconscious having narrowly survived after swimming over a mile to the shore, before being able to tell his rescuers the location of the accident and its survivors. As efforts were made to revive him, rescue parties went to the wrong location, Achill Head, based on guesswork. Falkus immediately upon recovering consciousness told the correct location but by then it was too late and the others had died from cold. His wife's remains and one other person's were recovered. [[Docunentary "Shark Island" by David Mullins RTE Documentaries September 2017]]
In 1952 Falkus married Lady Margaret Vane-Tempest-Stewart, second daughter of the [[Charles Vane-Tempest-Stewart, 7th Marquess of Londonderry|7th Marquess of Londonderry]], but the marriage was short-lived. By 1955 Falkus had settled in [[Eskdale, Cumbria|Eskdale]], [[Cumberland]], which he had come to know and love through his friendship with Bill Fowler, a bomber pilot from Long Yocking, Eskdale, who he had met in a prisoner of war camp. In 1958 Falkus married Kathleen Armstrong, daughter of a local farming family. He lived with her at Cragg Cottage, Eskdale, for most of the rest of his life, writing about fishing and natural history and making television films on related subjects. He wrote, produced and presented a series of ''[[Natural World (TV series)|The World About Us]]'' films for the BBC, and with the Nobel Prize-winning zoologist Professor [[Nikolaas Tinbergen|Niko Tinbergen]] he made a film about gull behaviour called ''Signals for Survival'' which won the Italia prize in 1969,<ref name=Indie/> and first prize for the BBC at the 1969 [[Rose d'Or|Montreux Film Festival]]. He was reportedly and according to his biographer, Chris Newton, a sexual predator, gaining the punning nickname "Huge Phallus" at the BBC.<ref name=Telegraph>{{cite web |last1=Clover |first1=Charles |title=A fisherman's women |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/non_fictionreviews/3671836/A-fishermans-women.html |publisher=The Telegraph |accessdate=14 July 2015 |date=15 March 2008}}</ref> He was still having affairs in his late sixties, upsetting his friends by deserting Kathleen, his wife of 25 years for a woman named Romille.<ref name=Telegraph/>
Falkus' masterwork ''Sea Trout Fishing, A Practical Guide'' (HF & G Witherby 1962, enlarged edition 1975) became a best-seller and has never been out of print; it "established his reputation as the father of modern sea-trout fishing" according to his biographer, Chris Newton. It was followed in 1984 by ''Salmon Fishing, a Practical Guide'', also a best-seller which remains in print.
Falkus was a controversial and outspoken figure, insisting on being right and bullying people.<ref name=Telegraph/>
He was awarded the [[Royal Geographical Society]]'s [[Cherry Kearton Medal and Award]] in 1982.<ref name="RGS">{{cite web|url=http://www.rgs.org/NR/rdonlyres/5733E422-4831-4451-B7D8-052E80E8CD75/0/MedalWinners19702012.pdf |title=Medals and Awards |publisher=[[Royal Geographical Society]] |accessdate=28 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131002055718/http://www.rgs.org/NR/rdonlyres/5733E422-4831-4451-B7D8-052E80E8CD75/0/MedalWinners19702012.pdf |archivedate=2 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Hugh Falkus died of cancer and bronchopneumonia at Cragg Cottage on 30 March 1996. His son Christopher had predeceased him, dying in 1995 of heart disease.
==Works== Falkus's works include:
===Films===
* ''The Signreaders'', 1964<ref name=Indie/> * ''Signals for Survival'', 1968, with [[Niko Tinbergen]]<ref name=Indie/> * ''The Riddle of the Rook'', 1973<ref name=Indie/> * ''Tender Trap'', 1974<ref name=Indie/> * ''Self-Portrait of a Happy Man'', 1976<ref name=Indie/> * ''Salmo the Leaper'', 1977<ref name=Indie/> * ''Highland Story'', 1979<ref name=Indie/>
===Books===
* ''Sea Trout Fishing'', 1962<ref name=Indie/> * ''The Stolen Years - Memories of a Country Boyhood'', 1965<ref name=Indie/> * ''Signals for Survival'', 1994 (with Niko Tinbergen) * ''Freshwater Fishing'', 1975 (with Fred Buller)<ref name=Indie/> * ''Nature Detective'', 1978<ref name=Indie/> * ''Salmon Fishing'', 1984<ref name=Indie/> * ''Falkus & Buller's Freshwater Fishing'', 1992 * ''Speycasting - A New Technique'', 1994<ref name=Indie/> * ''The Salmon and Sea Trout Fisher's Handbook'', 1994 (With Malcolm Greenhalgh) * ''Some of it was Fun'', 2003 == References == {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * ''Hugh Falkus: A Life on the Edge,'' a biography of Hugh Falkus by [http://www.chrisnewton.co.uk Chris Newton], was published in December 2007 by [http://www.medlarpress.com Medlar Press].
{{Authority control}}

{{Distinguish|Joe Plummer }} {{pp-move-indef}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox person |name = Joe Wurzelbacher |image = Samuel Joseph Wurzelbacher.jpg |alt = |caption = Wurzelbacher speaking in [[Elyria, Ohio|Elyria]], Ohio |birth_name = Samuel Joseph Wurzelbacher |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1973|12|3}} |birth_place = [[Toledo, Ohio|Toledo]], [[Ohio]], U.S. |residence = [[Holland, Ohio]], U.S. |citizenship = [[United States]] |other_names = "Joe the Plumber" |occupation = Commentator/[[correspondent]]
Former plumber's assistant |party = {{nowrap|[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] (2012–present)}} }} '''Samuel Joseph Wurzelbacher''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|w|ɜr|z|əl|b|ɑː|k|ər}}; born December 3, 1973), known as '''Joe the Plumber''', is an [[Americans|American]] [[conservatism in the United States|conservative]] activist and commentator. He gained national attention during the [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008 U.S. presidential election]] when, during a videotaped campaign stop in [[Ohio]] by then [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] nominee Senator [[Barack Obama]], Wurzelbacher asked Obama about his small business tax policy. Obama's response included the statement, "when you spread the wealth around, it's good for everybody." Obama's response was seized upon by [[conservative media]], and by Obama's rival, [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] nominee Senator [[John McCain]], as an indication that Obama was interested in the [[redistribution of wealth]] and had a [[socialism|socialist]] view of the economy. Wurzelbacher is a member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]].{{cite news |title=McCain: Joe the plumber right about Obama's socialist tax plan |url=http://www.boston.com/news/politics/politicalintelligence/2008/10/mccain_joe_the.html |first=Foon |last=Rhee |publisher=Political Intelligence (Boston Globe blog) |date=October 18, 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308022413/http://www.boston.com/news/politics/politicalintelligence/2008/10/mccain_joe_the.html |archivedate=March 8, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite news |title=Obama Fires a 'Robin Hood' Warning Shot |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/politics/item_iQRtIQHjYPcEoMZ0lJX0hI |first=Charles |last=Hurt |newspaper=The New York Post |date=October 16, 2008}} Since he expressed to then-Senator Obama that he was interested in purchasing a small plumbing business,{{cite news |title=Joe in the Spotlight |url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/10/16/joe-in-the-spotlight/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=0 |first=Larry |last=Rohter |newspaper=The New York Times |date=October 16, 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222230436/http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/10/16/joe-in-the-spotlight/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=0 |archivedate=February 22, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} Wurzelbacher was given the moniker "Joe the Plumber"{{cite news | title = 'Joe' pens memoir on his life, his dream | first = Tom | last = Troy | url = http://www.toledoblade.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20081220/NEWS09/812200366 | newspaper = [[The Blade (Toledo)|The Blade]] | publisher = [[Block Communications]] | location = [[Toledo, Ohio]] | issn = | date = December 20, 2008 | accessdate = September 12, 2009 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090122212627/http://www.toledoblade.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20081220%2FNEWS09%2F812200366 | archivedate = January 22, 2009 | df = mdy-all }} by the [[John McCain presidential campaign, 2008|McCain–Palin campaign]]. The campaign brought him in to make several appearances in campaign events in Ohio and McCain often referenced "Joe the Plumber" in campaign speeches and in the final presidential debate, as a metaphor for [[American middle class|middle-class Americans]].{{cite news|url = http://elections.foxnews.com/2008/10/16/joe-plumber-represents-hopes-dreams-political-football/|title = Joe the Plumber Represents Hopes, Dreams and Political Football|accessdate = October 29, 2008 | date = October 16, 2008 | publisher = Fox News|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081019204942/http://elections.foxnews.com/2008/10/16/joe-plumber-represents-hopes-dreams-political-football/|archivedate=October 19, 2008 }} Per this article's subtitle, "Joe the plumber is the nation's every man—embodying the American dream and representing the swing voter Barack Obama and John McCain want to reach"{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/us_elections_2008/7675278.stm | title = Doubts raised on US 'plumber Joe' | accessdate = October 29, 2008 | date = October 17, 2008 | publisher = BBC News | quote = Joe Wurzelbacher, 34, found himself at the center of a media frenzy on Thursday after "Joe the plumber" was mentioned 26 times during the final debate. | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081026081122/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/us_elections_2008/7675278.stm | archivedate = October 26, 2008 | df = mdy-all }} Wurzelbacher became a prominent conservative activist, commentator, author and [[motivational speaker]]. In 2012, he [[United States House of Representatives elections in Ohio, 2012#District 9|ran]] on the Republican ticket to represent [[Ohio's 9th congressional district]] in the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]], losing to Democratic incumbent [[Marcy Kaptur]].{{cite news |title=Marcy Kaptur coasts to win in 9th District congressional race |url=http://www.cleveland.com/sun/all/index.ssf/2012/11/marcie_kaptur_coasts_to_win_in.html |publisher=Sun News |first=Joe |last=Noga |date=November 7, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160424105843/http://www.cleveland.com/sun/all/index.ssf/2012/11/marcie_kaptur_coasts_to_win_in.html |archivedate=April 24, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} ==Early life, education, and business career== Wurzelbacher was born in [[Toledo, Ohio]], to Kay and Frank Wurzelbacher. The family moved to Florida when he was young, then returned to Toledo when he was in the middle of high school. After high school, Wurzelbacher enlisted in the [[United States Air Force]], and was stationed in [[Alaska]] and [[North Dakota]]. Wurzelbacher left the Air Force in 1996 and worked as a plumber's assistant, but then switched careers and started working for the telecommunications company [[Global Crossing]]. He also married, had a son, and then divorced during this time. ==2008 presidential election== ===Encounter with Barack Obama=== On October 12, 2008, during a campaign break before the final presidential debate at Hofstra University, Obama visited a working class Toledo, Ohio neighborhood.{{cite web | url = http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalpunch/2008/10/in-working-clas.html | title = In Working-Class Ohio, Obama Meets Amorous Dogs, Skeptical Plumber | accessdate = October 20, 2008 | date = October 12, 2008 | authorlink = Jake Tapper | last = Tapper | first = Jake | publisher = ABC News | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081016044809/http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalpunch/2008/10/in-working-clas.html | archivedate = October 16, 2008 | df = mdy-all }} Wurzelbacher watched as the candidate engaged numerous residents in conversation. He made his way through the crowd to ask Obama about his tax plan.{{cite web |url=http://toledoblade.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20081016/NEWS09/810160418 |title='Joe the plumber' isn't licensed |accessdate=October 29, 2008 |date=October 16, 2008 |first=Larry |last=Vellequette |author2=Troy, Tom |publisher=[[Toledo Blade]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081028013622/http://www.toledoblade.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20081016%2FNEWS09%2F810160418 |archivedate=October 28, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} Wurzelbacher suggested that Obama's tax plan would be at odds with "the American dream."{{cite news|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/16/us/politics/16plumber.html|title = Plumber From Ohio Is Thrust Into Spotlight |last = Rohter |first = Larry |publisher = New York Times |date = October 15, 2008 | accessdate = October 17, 2008}} Wurzelbacher said, "I'm getting ready to buy a company that makes 250 to 280 thousand dollars a year. Your new tax plan's going to tax me more, isn't it?"{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/17/us/politics/17joe.html |title=Real Deal on 'Joe the Plumber' Reveals New Slant |work=The New York Times |date=October 16, 2008 |author=Rohter, Larry. |accessdate=October 16, 2008 }} Obama responded with an explanation of how his tax plan would affect a small business in this bracket. Obama said, "If you're a small business, which you would qualify, first of all, you would get a 50 percent tax credit so you'd get a cut in taxes for your health care costs. So you would actually get a tax cut on that part. If your revenue is above 250, then from 250 down, your taxes are going to stay the same. It is true that, say for 250 up — from 250 to 300 or so, so for that additional amount, you'd go from 36 to 39 percent, which is what it was under [[Bill Clinton]]."{{cite news|url = http://abcnews.go.com/Video/playerIndex?id=6031110|title = ABC News video 'Joe the Plumber'|date = October 15, 2008|accessdate = October 20, 2008|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081019073936/http://abcnews.go.com/video/playerIndex?id=6031110|archivedate = October 19, 2008|df = mdy-all}} Obama also said, "It's not that I want to punish your success. I just want to make sure that everybody who is behind you, that they've got a chance at success, too... My attitude is that if the economy's good for folks from the bottom up, it's gonna be good for everybody. If you've got a plumbing business, you're gonna be better off [...] if you've got a whole bunch of customers who can afford to hire you, and right now everybody's so pinched that business is bad for everybody and I think when you spread the wealth around, it's good for everybody."{{cite news|url = http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5ha9qKZFKzFvH74G3c5PxRG_lHRIAD93RC8FG0 | title = McCain, Obama get tough, personal in final debate | last = Fouhy | first = Beth | date = October 15, 2008 |accessdate = October 17, 2008 |agency = Associated Press|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081021004119/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5ha9qKZFKzFvH74G3c5PxRG_lHRIAD93RC8FG0|archivedate=October 21, 2008 }}{{cite web | url = http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalpunch/2008/10/spread-the-weal.html | title = 'Spread the Wealth'? | accessdate = October 29, 2008 | date = October 14, 2008 | authorlink = Jake Tapper | last = Tapper | first = Jake | work = "Political Punch" blog | publisher = ABCNews.com | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081026174223/http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalpunch/2008/10/spread-the-weal.html | archivedate = October 26, 2008 | df = mdy-all }} ===Presidential debate=== {{Main|United States presidential election debates, 2008}} During the third and final Presidential debate on October 15, 2008, at [[Hofstra University]], many references were made to "Joe the Plumber."{{Dead link|date=June 2010}}{{cite news | url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/us_elections/article4952909.ece | title = Joe the plumber is real hero of the debate | accessdate = October 31, 2008 | date = October 16, 2008 | last = Barrowclough | first = Anne | publisher = The Times | location = London | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081017081832/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/us_elections/article4952909.ece | archivedate = October 17, 2008 | df = mdy-all }} In the debate, McCain repeatedly brought up "Joe the Plumber" and Obama and McCain then made statements aimed directly at Wurzelbacher. As a result, subsequent [[News media|media]] attention was directed at Wurzelbacher.{{cite news|url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5gJsPHiQlgYvAsrHz9mvHJlezQJLwD93RONUO0 |first=John |last=Seewer |date=October 16, 2008 |title='Joe the Plumber' says he has no plumbing license |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=October 17, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081019153648/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5gJsPHiQlgYvAsrHz9mvHJlezQJLwD93RONUO0 |archivedate=October 19, 2008 }}{{cite news | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/10/16/AR2008101600099.html?hpid%3Dtopnews&sub=new | title = Candidates Make A Name for This Guy Joe | accessdate = October 31, 2008 | date = October 16, 2008 | last = Shales | first = Tom | publisher = The Washington Post | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121108181410/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/10/16/AR2008101600099.html?hpid=topnews&sub=new | archivedate = November 8, 2012 | df = mdy-all }}{{cite news | url = https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20081015.wdebate1015/BNStory/International | title = McCain invokes 'Joe the Plumber' to heap scorn on Obama | accessdate = October 31, 2008 | date = October 16, 2008 | last = Ibbitson | first = John | publisher = [[The Globe and Mail]] | location = Toronto | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081019113939/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20081015.wdebate1015/BNStory/International/ | archivedate = October 19, 2008 | df = mdy-all }} After the debate, Wurzelbacher did not declare his vote for either candidate. He expressed concern that Obama's plans were "one step closer to [[socialism]]."{{cite web |url=http://www.toledoblade.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20081016/NEWS09/810160418 |title='Joe the Plumber' is focus of presidential debate's first few minutes |last=Tharp |first=Bridget |author2=Zaborney, Mark |publisher=Toledo Blade |date=October 16, 2008 |accessdate=October 16, 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081018154702/http://www.toledoblade.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20081016%2FNEWS09%2F810160418 |archivedate=October 18, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} Obama's running mate [[Joe Biden]] argued that 98% of small businesses take in less than $250,000 a year in income and thus wouldn't be subject to higher taxes under Obama's plan. McCain stated that Wurzelbacher would see higher taxes under Obama's plan.{{cite news | url = http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2008/10/16/biden-questions-notion-of-this-guy-joe-the-plumber/ | title = Biden questions 'notion of this guy Joe the plumber' | accessdate = October 31, 2008 | date = October 16, 2008 | last = Sinderbrand | first = Rebecca | publisher = CNN | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081102181610/http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2008/10/16/biden-questions-notion-of-this-guy-joe-the-plumber/ | archivedate = November 2, 2008 | df = mdy-all }} ===2008 media appearances=== [[File:Wurzelbacher & McCain joint apperance at Elyria.jpg|thumb|Wurzelbacher and John McCain in a joint appearance at [[Elyria, Ohio]]]] Wurzelbacher spoke to [[Katie Couric]] of ''[[CBS Evening News]]'' on October 15, shortly after the conclusion of the final debate. Asked whether Obama's proposed $250,000 tax threshold would affect him, Wurzelbacher replied: "Not right now at presently, but (...) he's going to do that now for people who make $250,000 a year. When's he going to decide that $100,000 is too much? (...) You're on a slippery slope here. You vote on somebody who decides that $250,000 and you're rich? And $100,000 and you're rich? (...) Where does it end?" He also said: "I asked the question but I still got a tap dance ...almost as good as [[Sammy Davis, Jr.]]"{{cite news |url = http://www.cbsnews.com/blogs/2008/10/16/politics/horserace/entry4525242.shtml |last = Montopoli |first = Brian |date = October 16, 2008 |accessdate = October 16, 2008 |title = Joe The Plumber's Chat With Couric |publisher = [[CBS News]] |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081016233400/http://www.cbsnews.com/blogs/2008/10/16/politics/horserace/entry4525242.shtml |archivedate = October 16, 2008 |df = mdy-all }} Wurzelbacher held a press conference at his home on the morning of October 16, following the debates, where he refused to express support for either candidate. "I'm not telling anybody anything" about which candidate he prefers, he said, adding, "It's a private booth. I want the American people to vote for who they want to vote for."{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/politics/la-na-campaign17-2008oct17,0,373757.story |title='Joe the Plumber' still a topic for McCain, Obama |accessdate=October 16, 2008 |date=October 16, 2008 |work= |publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] |first=Seema |last=Mehta |author2=Michael Muskal |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081018012808/http://www.latimes.com/news/politics/la-na-campaign17-2008oct17,0,373757.story |archivedate=October 18, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} On October 16, Wurzelbacher appeared on ''[[Your World with Neil Cavuto]]'' on [[Fox News]]. [[Neil Cavuto]] asked if Wurzelbacher was persuaded by Obama's plan. Wurzelbacher said that he was not and that he was more frightened upon hearing it. Wurzelbacher suggested that Obama's plan was socialist in nature. That same day, Wurzelbacher also appeared on ''[[Good Morning America]]''. [[Diane Sawyer]] asked him if he was taking home $250,000 now, Wurzelbacher said with a laugh "No, not even close."{{cite web |url = http://abcnews.go.com/Video/playerIndex?id=6047458 |last = ABC Staff |date = October 16, 2008 |accessdate = October 16, 2008 |title = Meet Joe the Plumber |publisher = [[ABC News]] |work = Video |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081017221710/http://abcnews.go.com/Video/playerIndex?id=6047458 |archivedate = October 17, 2008 |df = mdy-all }} Sawyer asked Wurzelbacher, "And the McCain camp, some people have said did they contact you and tell you that you were going to be a major part of this, and had they contacted you before that encounter with Senator Obama?" Wurzelbacher answered, "Oh no, no, no one's contacted me as far as if I was going to be on the debate or as far as my name being used. No. I have been contacted by them and asked to show up at a rally. But, other than that, no. I just happened to be here and Barack Obama happened to show up." On November 2, Wurzelbacher appeared again on ''Your World with Neil Cavuto'', where he expressed concern that Barack Obama's tax plans would go down "a slippery slope" and eventually raise his taxes. Wurzelbacher also questioned Obama's patriotism saying "there's too many questions with Barack Obama, and his loyalty to our country."{{cite web|url=http://rawstory.com/news/2008/Joe_Plumber_questions_Obamas_loyalty_to_1102.html|title=Joe the Plumber questions Obama's loyalty to America|date=November 2, 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081106042640/http://rawstory.com/news/2008/Joe_Plumber_questions_Obamas_loyalty_to_1102.html|archivedate=November 6, 2008|df=mdy-all}} ===References on the campaign trail=== On October 18, McCain told a campaign rally in [[Melbourne, Florida]] that he had phoned Wurzelbacher for the first time on October 17. McCain said, "He's a great guy, proud of his grandfather who served in the US Marine Corps. We're going to fight for Joe, my friends, we are going to fight for him. The question Joe asked about our economy is important, because Senator Obama's plan would raise taxes on small businesses that employ 16 million Americans. Senator Obama's plan will kill those jobs at just the time when we need to be creating more jobs. My plan will create jobs, and that's what America needs."{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/world/view/20081018-167115/John-McCain-telephones-Joe-the-Plumber|title=John McCain telephones 'Joe the Plumber'|last=Staff|date=October 18, 2008|work=Breaking News / World|publisher=inquirer.net|accessdate=December 4, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081019130534/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/world/view/20081018-167115/John-McCain-telephones-Joe-the-Plumber|archivedate=October 19, 2008|df=mdy-all}} The [[McCain-Palin]] campaign's senior strategist [[Steve Schmidt]] said that John McCain's strategy in the final weeks of the presidential campaign was based primarily on his differences with Obama on economic issues, which they would continue to highlight through the story of Joe the Plumber.{{cite news |last=Draper |first=Robert |title=The Making (and Remaking) of McCain |publisher=''[[The New York Times Magazine]]'' |date=October 26, 2008 |accessdate=October 26, 2008 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/26/magazine/26mccain-t.html |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081026045826/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/26/magazine/26mccain-t.html |archivedate=October 26, 2008 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/17/us/politics/17campaign.html?_r=1&oref=slogin|title=Polls Cause Campaigns to Change Their Itineraries |last=Nagourney|first=Adam|author2=Jim Rutenberg|date=October 16, 2008|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=October 17, 2008}} After the final presidential debate, McCain and his running mate [[Sarah Palin]] frequently repeated the charge in campaign speeches that "Joe the Plumber" would pay higher taxes under Obama and Biden's plan, although according to tax analysts neither Wurzelbacher nor the company he works for would actually be subject to higher taxes under Obama's tax plan. Obama's "spread the wealth around" quote was later used by the McCain campaign, comparing the Democratic policies to [[socialism]].{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/washingtondc/la-na-campaign19-2008oct19,0,6341003.story|title=John McCain compares Barack Obama's policies to socialism|last=Drogin|first=Bob|author2=Mark Z. Barabak|date=October 18, 2008|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=October 19, 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081019174454/http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/washingtondc/la-na-campaign19-2008oct19,0,6341003.story|archivedate=October 19, 2008|df=mdy-all}} McCain said, "[Obama] wants government to take Joe's money and give it to somebody else." Obama said in a campaign rally on October 24 that McCain was "not fighting for Joe the Plumber. He's fighting for Joe the [[Hedge fund|Hedge Fund]] Manager... He likes to talk about Joe the Plumber but he's in cahoots with Joe the [[Chief executive officer|CEO]]." Obama then promoted a plan for [[Middle class|middle-class]] [[tax cut]]s and "asked for a show of hands at the rally in the [[Richmond Coliseum]] from those making less than $250,000. Nearly all of the 13,000 people raised their hands."{{cite web |last=Miller |first=S.A. |title=Obama: McCain's for 'Joe the CEO' |publisher=''[[The Washington Times]]'' |date=October 22, 2008 |accessdate=March 2, 2016 |url=http://washingtontimes.com/news/2008/oct/22/obama-mccains-joe-ceo/ |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303184838/http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2008/oct/22/obama-mccains-joe-ceo/ |archivedate=March 3, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} Aides to the McCain-Palin campaign said on October 24 that they would "spend heavily" on a new TV advertisement invoking Wurzelbacher's nickname. The ad would feature "several different people looking into the camera and saying, 'I'm Joe the Plumber.' One man accuses Obama of wanting to use the man's 'sweat to pay for his trillion dollars in new spending.{{' "}}{{cite news |last=Abramowitz |first=Michael |title=As an Issue, Taxes Favor Obama: Polls Lean Toward Democrat on a Traditional GOP Strength |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/10/23/AR2008102303363.html |publisher=''[[Washington Post]]'' |date=October 24, 2008 In May 2009, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine reported that Wurzelbacher was quitting the Republican Party.{{cite news |work=Time magazine |title=Republicans in Distress: Is the Party Over? |author=Michael Grunwald |date=May 7, 2009 |url=http://www.time.com/time/politics/article/0,8599,1896588,00.html |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100623072006/http://www.time.com/time/politics/article/0,8599,1896588,00.html |archivedate=June 23, 2010 |df=mdy-all }} On June 25, 2009, Wurzelbacher spoke at an event called "Pints and Politics" in [[Wausau, Wisconsin]]. During his speech, Wurzelbacher questioned why [[Chris Dodd]] hadn't been "strung up" yet. He stated that the [[Founding Fathers]] "knew socialism doesn't work. They knew communism doesn't work."[https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20090801043104/http://www.wausaudailyherald.com/article/20090626/WDH0101/906260520/1981 ] On February 13, 2010, Wurzelbacher attended a political event for [[Pennsylvania]] gubernatorial candidate [[Sam Rohrer]]. Speaking to a reporter afterwards, Wurzelbacher said that "McCain was trying to use [him]", and accused McCain of having "really screwed [his] life up".{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/blogs/2010/02/15/politics/politicalhotsheet/entry6209201.shtml|title="Joe the Plumber" Bashes John McCain|date=February 15, 2009|first=Tucker|last=Reals|publisher=CBS News|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100216175424/http://www.cbsnews.com/blogs/2010/02/15/politics/politicalhotsheet/entry6209201.shtml|archivedate=February 16, 2010|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|title= Joe the Plumber dumps on John McCain and Sarah Palin|first= Richard|last= Adams|newspaper= [[The Guardian|Guardian]]|date= February 16, 2010|url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/richard-adams-blog/2010/feb/16/joe-the-plumber-palin-mccain|location= London|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160515034151/http://www.theguardian.com/world/richard-adams-blog/2010/feb/16/joe-the-plumber-palin-mccain|archivedate= May 15, 2016|df= mdy-all}} In [[Wisconsin]], on February 2011, he spoke at a counter-demonstration during protests against Governor [[Scott Walker (politician)|Scott Walker]]'s attempts to abolish [[collective bargaining]] rights of some public employees.{{cite news |title= Wisconsin budget cuts: Madison rally attracts thousands |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-12517062 |agency= BBC News |date= February 19, 2011 |accessdate= February 20, 2011 |quote= His message was: "Unions don't deserve anything, you don't deserve anything, you work for it yourself!" |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110220083702/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-12517062 |archivedate= February 20, 2011 |df= mdy-all }} In 2012, Wurzelbacher started the news site "Joe For America". In February 2014, Wurzelbacher took a job at a [[Jeep]] plant which required him to be a member of the [[United Auto Workers]]. He complained that his colleagues have called him a "Tea-bagger".{{cite news|url=http://www.toledoblade.com/Politics/2014/02/18/Joe-the-Plumber-says-he-s-in-UAW.html|date=February 17, 2014|title='Joe the Plumber' says he's in UAW|first=Tom|last=Troy|accessdate=February 18, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140306163354/http://www.toledoblade.com/Politics/2014/02/18/Joe-the-Plumber-says-he-s-in-UAW.html|archivedate=March 6, 2014|df=mdy-all}} The ''[[Washington Post]]'', citing Sean McAlinden, who has studied the auto-bailout as the Chief Economist for the non-profit [[Center for Automotive Research]], commented that an "irony" is "that Joe the Plumber may not have gotten this auto job if it weren't for the hated bailout of the auto industry" which was "first championed by Bush" but attacked by conservatives when implemented by Obama. McAliden is quoted saying "He wouldn't have gotten a job in Toledo if Chrysler hadn't been bailed out..Chrysler would have shut down immediately. No production; no jobs; no pension payments; no nothing."{{cite news|last1=Sargent|first1=Greg|title=Joe the Plumber Gets a New Job|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/plum-line/wp/2014/02/18/joe-the-plumber-gets-a-new-job/|accessdate=5 August 2016|work=The Washington Post|date=February 18, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822202514/https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/plum-line/wp/2014/02/18/joe-the-plumber-gets-a-new-job/|archivedate=August 22, 2016|df=mdy-all}} For his part, Joe indicated he has no problem with unions per se, stating "Private unions, such as the UAW, is a choice between employees and employers. If that is what they want, then who am I to say you can't have it?". Wurzelbacher voted for [[Donald Trump]] in the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3477109/Joe-Plumber-praises-Trump-cites-beautiful-women.html|title=Joe the Plumber says he's voting for Trump because has a model wife|author=|date=|website=dailymail.co.uk|accessdate=May 4, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160608062038/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3477109/Joe-Plumber-praises-Trump-cites-beautiful-women.html|archivedate=June 8, 2016|df=mdy-all}} ==2012 congressional election== ===Draft movement=== After his meeting with Barack Obama, a campaign to [[draft (politics)|draft]] Wurzelbacher to run for the [[United States House of Representatives]] in the 2010 election started with the website joewurzelbacher2010.com.{{cite web |url= http://www.wsbt.com/news/election/presidentialnews/31217114.html |last=Staff |date=October 18, 2008 |accessdate = October 27, 2008 |title = Joe the Plumber to become Joe the Politician? |publisher = [[WSBT-TV]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081022173119/http://www.wsbt.com/news/election/presidentialnews/31217114.html |archivedate=October 22, 2008 }} The ''[[Washington Times]]'' and the ''[[Boston Herald]]'' reported that the campaign's goal was to draft Wurzelbacher to run against Rep. |publisher = [[NBC]] }} It encouraged visitors to sign an online petition that supported Wurzelbacher's run for office.{{cite web |url = http://briefingroom.thehill.com/2008/10/17/joe-for-congress/ |date = October 17, 2008 |accessdate = October 27, 2008 |title = Joe for Congress? archivedate=March 8, 2012 | df=mdy-all }} He lost the election, with Kaptur, who had been the heavy favorite, receiving over 70% of the vote. ==Controversies== ===Plumbing credentials=== Regarding his statement to Barack Obama about intending to buy the plumbing firm that employed him, Wurzelbacher later said that the idea of buying the company was discussed during his job interview six years prior. Court records show that Wurzelbacher made $40,000 in 2006. As part of the background on McCain's use of "Joe the Plumber" during the 2008 campaign, several media outlets researched his professional plumbing credentials. One ''[[Toledo Blade]]'' article stated: "Mr. Wurzelbacher said he works under Al Newell's license, but according to Ohio building regulations, he must maintain his own license to do plumbing work. He is also not registered to operate as a plumber in Ohio, which means he's not a plumber." "Mr. Joseph [business manager of the local union] said Mr. Wurzelbacher could only legally work in the townships, but not in any municipality in Lucas County or elsewhere in the country."{{cite web |url = http://www.toledoblade.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20081016/NEWS09/810160418/-1/NEWS |last = Vellequette |first = Larry |date = October 16, 2008 |accessdate = December 11, 2008 |title = 'Joe the plumber' isn't licensed |publisher = [[Toledo Blade]] |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081210034948/http://www.toledoblade.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20081016%2FNEWS09%2F810160418%2F-1%2FNEWS |archivedate = December 10, 2008 |df = mdy-all }} Wurzelbacher later stated that he was no longer employed at Newell. Wurzelbacher was not a member of the [[United Association|United Association of Plumbers and Pipefitters]] (the national plumbers' union) and never served an [[apprenticeship]]. ===Tax controversy=== [[ABC News]] reported on October 16, 2008, that there was a judgment [[lien]] against Wurzelbacher for non-payment of $1,182 in owed Ohio state income taxes dating to January 2007, but "no action has been taken against him outside of filing the lien." Barb Losie, deputy clerk of the [[Lucas County, Ohio|Lucas County]] Court of Common Pleas, said that "there is a 99 percent chance [Wurzelbacher] doesn't know about the lien, unless he did a credit report or was ready to pay his taxes."{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/Vote2008/story?id=6047360&page=1 |title=America's Overnight Sensation Joe the Plumber Owes $1,200 in Taxes |accessdate=October 25, 2008 |last=Ibanga |first=Imaeyan |author2=Goldman, Russell |date=October 16, 2008 |publisher=[[ABC News]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081023053035/http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/Vote2008/story?id=6047360&page=1 |archivedate=October 23, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} While on ''[[Hannity & Colmes]]'', Wurzelbacher stated that he was unaware of the tax lien prior to it being reported in the press.[[Hannity & Colmes]]. [http://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2008/10/joe_the_plumber_on_hannity_col.html Joe the Plumber on "Hannity & Colmes"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081025033213/http://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2008/10/joe_the_plumber_on_hannity_col.html |date=October 25, 2008 }}, realclearpolitics.com, October 20, 2008. (Transcript) The taxes were paid on November 6.[http://www.bostonherald.com/news/us_politics/view.bg?articleid=1130776&srvc=2008campnews&position=14 Joe the Plumber pays off back taxes in Ohio] Associated Press, Friday, November 7, 2008 ===Database search controversy=== {{Main|Controversial Ohio database searches of Joe Wurzelbacher}} Prior to the 2008 election, Vanessa Niekamp, an employee of Ohio's Department of Job and Family Services (ODJFS), at the behest of its director, [[Helen Jones-Kelley]], used state computers to search for information on Joe Wurzelbacher. On November 20, 2008, Niekamp reported the violation to the State Inspector General. State and local officials completed an investigation into Jones-Kelley's order, concluding that the searches were improper.{{cite web |last=Ludlow |first=Randy |url=http://www.dispatch.com/live/content/local_news/stories/2008/10/29/joe30.html?sid=101 |title=Checks on 'Joe' more extensive than first acknowledged | The Columbus Dispatch |publisher= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100225234705/http://www.dispatch.com/live/content/local_news/stories/2008/10/29/joe30.html?sid=101 |archivedate=February 25, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}[http://watchdog.ohio.gov/investigations/2008299.pdf ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081231153533/http://watchdog.ohio.gov/investigations/2008299.pdf |date=December 31, 2008 }} On December 17, 2008, Jones-Kelley resigned.{{cite web |url = http://www.10tv.com/content/stories/2008/12/18/story_kelley.html |date = 2008-12-17 |accessdate = Aug 18, 2014 |title = Director Who Improperly Searched 'Joe The Plumber' Resigns |agency = Associated Press |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140819145621/http://www.10tv.com/content/stories/2008/12/18/story_kelley.html |archivedate = August 19, 2014 |df = mdy-all }} In response to the event, [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Ohio state representative [[Shannon Jones]] sponsored House Bill 648, which mandates civil and criminal penalties for improper access of personal information on state databases.{{cite web |url = http://www.dispatchpolitics.com/live/content/local_news/stories/2008/12/05/copy/vanessa.ART_ART_12-05-08_A1_NQC4TEM.html?sid=101 |date = December 5, 2008 |accessdate = floor actions |agency=Associated Press }}{{dead link|date=December 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} On March 5, 2009, on behalf of Joe Wurzelbacher, [[Judicial Watch]] filed a lawsuit in a [[U.S. District Court]] in Columbus{{cite web |url=http://www.western-star.com/n/content/oh/story/news/local/2009/03/06/ddn030609joesuit.html |date=March 6, 2009 |accessdate=March 9, 2009 |title='Joe On August 4, 2010, the U.S District Court in Columbus dismissed the lawsuit on the grounds that the state database search didn't amount to a constitutional violation to the right to privacy.{{cite web |url = http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2010/aug/5/joe-the-plumber-loses-suit-over-file-snooping/ |title = 'Joe the Plumber' loses suit over file-snooping |date = August 5, 2010 |publisher = ''[[The Washington Times]] |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100818194647/http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2010/aug/5/joe-the-plumber-loses-suit-over-file-snooping/ |archivedate = August 18, 2010 |df = mdy-all }} On March 25, 2012, the [[U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit]] affirmed the dismissal.[http://www.ca6.uscourts.gov/opinions.pdf/12a0083p-06.pdf Wurzelbacher v. Jones-Kelly] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140212010701/http://www.ca6.uscourts.gov/opinions.pdf/12a0083p-06.pdf |date=February 12, 2014 }} March 27, 2012. Retrieved Aug. 19, 2014. On October 14, 2009, the ''[[Columbus Dispatch]]'' reported that, "A former contractor for the Ohio Association of Chiefs of Police has been charged with rummaging through state computers to retrieve confidential information about 'Joe the Plumber.'" }}[http://thehill.com/video/campaign/233575-joe-the-plumber-campaign-video-blames-holocaust-on-gun-control 'Joe the Plumber' campaign video blames Holocaust on gun control] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120625020204/http://thehill.com/video/campaign/233575-joe-the-plumber-campaign-video-blames-holocaust-on-gun-control |date=June 25, 2012 }} by Cameron Joseph, ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'', June 19, 2012.[http://cleveland.cbslocal.com/2012/06/20/joe-the-plumber-links-holocaust-with-gun-control/ ‘Joe The Plumber’ Links Holocaust With Gun Control] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120621055211/http://cleveland.cbslocal.com/2012/06/20/joe-the-plumber-links-holocaust-with-gun-control/ |date=June 21, 2012 }}, CBS Cleveland, June 20, 2012. The video drew sharp criticism from the [[National Jewish Democratic Council]] (NJDC) and [[Ohio Democratic Party]] Chairman [[Chris Redfern]].[http://www.toledoblade.com/Politics/2012/06/19/Joe-the-Plumber-releases-controversial-video.html Wurzelbacher video blames Holocaust on gun control] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120625020848/http://www.toledoblade.com/Politics/2012/06/19/Joe-the-Plumber-releases-controversial-video.html |date=June 25, 2012 }} by Ignazio Messina, ''[[Toledo Blade]]'' (Toledoblade.com), June 19, 2012. Wurzelbacher subsequently defended the video, stating that "Different countries around the world have tried to disarm their citizens, and then have tried to exterminate their own now-unarmed citizens. If people are looking to be offended by this video, they are probably serving a political agenda. Unfortunately there are a lot of whiners out there." Wurzelbacher's spokesman, Phil Christofanelli, also defended the video, stating that Wurzelbacher was a "student of history" who knows that the Founding Fathers "understood that the 2nd Amendment was always the people's last defense against tyrannical government." ===Illegal immigration remark=== In August 2012, Wurzelbacher drew criticism for a comment he made about illegal immigration. During a campaign rally for Arizona State Senator [[Lori Klein (politician)|Lori Klein]], Wurzelbacher said, "For years I've said, you know, put a damn fence on the border, going to Mexico and start shooting."{{cite web |url=http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2012/08/14/joe-the-plumber-calls-to-start-shooting-immigrants-at-the-border/ |title=Joe the Plumber calls to 'start shooting' immigrants at the border |publisher=The Raw Story |date=August 14, 2012 |accessdate=February 18, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130606173447/http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2012/08/14/joe-the-plumber-calls-to-start-shooting-immigrants-at-the-border/ |archivedate=June 6, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} When asked about the comment later, he said that he didn't care about being "politically incorrect." Klein defended Wurzelbacher, telling reporters his comments were just a joke.{{cite news |last=Bingham |first=Amy |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/08/13/joe-the-plumber_n_1773590.html |title=Joe The Plumber: 'Put A Damn Fence On The Border Going To Mexico And Start Shooting' |publisher=The Huffington Post |date=August 13, 2012 |accessdate=February 18, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120905090656/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/08/13/joe-the-plumber_n_1773590.html |archivedate=September 5, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web|last=Bingham |first=Amy |url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/politics/2012/08/joe-the-plumber-unfiltered-build-a-damn-fence-and-start-shooting/ |title=Joe the Plumber Unfiltered: Build a 'Damn Fence' and 'Start Shooting' |publisher=Abc News |date=August 14, 2012 |accessdate=February 18, 2013}} ===Published reaction to Santa Barbara, California, mass shooting=== In an open letter to the parents of victims who died in the [[2014 Isla Vista killings]],{{cite web | title=An Open Letter: To the parents of the victims murdered by Elliot Rodger | last=Wurzelbacher | first=Joe | date=27 May 2014 | publisher=BarbWire: "Politics and Culture / News and Opinion From a Decidedly Biblical Worldview" | url=http://barbwire.com/2014/05/27/open-letter-parents-victims-murdered-elliot-rodger/ | accessdate=27 May 2014 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140528073405/http://barbwire.com/2014/05/27/open-letter-parents-victims-murdered-elliot-rodger/ | archivedate=May 28, 2014 | df=mdy-all }} Wurzelbacher wrote of his right to "protect my family" stating, "As harsh as this sounds—your dead kids don't trump my Constitutional rights ... We still have the Right to Bear Arms ... Any feelings you have toward my rights being taken away from me, lose those."{{cite news | title='Joe the Plumber' Pens 'Harsh' Open Letter to Isla Vista Relatives | last=Gittens | first=Hasani | date=27 May 2014 | publisher=NBC News | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/isla-vista-rampage/joe-plumber-pens-harsh-open-letter-isla-vista-relatives-n115561 | accessdate=27 May 2014 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140528004803/http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/isla-vista-rampage/joe-plumber-pens-harsh-open-letter-isla-vista-relatives-n115561 | archivedate=May 28, 2014 | {{Use American English|date=December 2016}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox protected area | name = {{Nowrap|Louisiana Purchase Historic State Park}} | iucn_category = | iucn_ref = | photo = Louisiana Purchase State Park 002.jpg | photo_caption = | map = | map_image = | map_size = | map_caption = | relief = | location = [[Arkansas]], United States | nearest_city = | nearest_town = | coordinates = {{coord|34|38|44.5|N|91|03|14.3|W|region:US-AR_type:landmark_scale:100000|display=inline,title}} | coords_ref = | length = | length_mi = | length_km = | width = | width_mi = | width_km = | area_acre = 37.5 | area_ref = | elevation = | elevation_avg = | elevation_min = | elevation_max = | dimensions = | designation = | authorized = | created = | designated = | established = 1961 | named_for = [[Louisiana Purchase]] | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | visitation_ref = | governing_body = Division of State Parks, [[Arkansas Department of Parks and Tourism]] | administrator = | operator = | owner = | website = [http://www.arkansasstateparks.com/louisianapurchase Louisiana Purchase Historic State Park] | embedded = }} The '''Louisiana Purchase Historic State Park''' commemorates the initial point from which the lands acquired through the [[Louisiana Purchase]] (1803) were subsequently surveyed. The [[protected area]] encompasses {{convert|37.5|acre|ha}} of forested [[wetlands]], a landform which is regionally in decline due to agricultural development practices that include draining such areas. In the center of the park is a {{convert|6|ft|m|adj=on}} marker erected in 1926 on the survey point by the L'Anguille Chapter of the [[Daughters of the American Revolution]]. The site was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] (1972) and designated as a [[National Historic Landmark]] (1993).{{NRISref|2009a}} ==Description== The historic state park is located at the eastern end of [[Arkansas Highway 362]], southeast of [[Blackton, Arkansas]], at the [[tripoint]] junction of [[Lee County, Arkansas|Lee]], [[Monroe County, Arkansas|Monroe]], and [[Phillips County, Arkansas|Phillips]] counties. It is a {{convert|37.5|acre|ha|adj=on}} parcel of [[swamp]], or forested wetlands, which is remarkably unchanged from the time when surveyors came here in 1815. This type of wetlands is becoming increasingly rare because of the practice of draining and clearing such land for agricultural use. The boardwalk, {{convert|950|ft|m}} long, leads to the site of the marker, with occasional interpretive signs describing the ecology of the area and the significance of the [[national historic landmark]].{{Cite journal|title=National Historic Landmark Nomination: Louisiana Purchase Survey Marker / Louisiana Purchase Initial Point Site|url={{NHLS url|id=72000206}} |format=pdf|author=William D. Baker|date=September 16, 1991|publisher=National Park Service}} The Louisiana Purchase Survey Marker is {{convert|6|ft|m}} in height and is about {{convert|4.5|ft|m}} wide at the base. It typically stands in about {{convert|1|ft|m}} of swamp water. The inscription reads:
''"This stone marks the base established November 10, 1815, from which the lands of the Louisiana Purchase were surveyed by [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|United States engineers]]. The first survey from this point was made to satisfy the claims of the soldiers of the [[War of 1812]] with land bounties"''.
==History== On April 30, 1803, negotiators for the United States and the [[First French Empire]], signed the Louisiana Purchase agreement, by which the United States acquired {{convert|830000|sqmi|sqkm}} of land west of the [[Mississippi River]], doubling its size. President Thomas Jefferson commissioned the [[Lewis and Clark Expedition]], which traveled west along the Missouri and associated rivers, eventually reaching the Pacific Coast, from 1804 to 1806. President [[James Monroe]] ordered a survey of the territory in 1815, in order to permit the orderly award of land in the territory to military veterans of the War of 1812. [[Prospect K. Robbins]] and [[Joseph C. Brown]] were commissioned to identify a starting point for the survey work in what is now eastern Arkansas. The team led by Robbins traveled north from the mouth of the [[Arkansas River]], while that of Brown traveled west from the mouth of the [[St. Francis River]]. On October 27, 1815, Robbins' party crossed the east-west line laid down by Brown's party at this point, formally establishing the [[Fifth Principal Meridian]]. The {{convert|55|mi|km}} of land Robbins traversed is even today some of the most difficult terrain in the state to negotiate. Brown's party traversed {{convert|26|mi|km}} of land alternately described as "good for farming" and containing "briers and thickets in abundance". Brown's party eventually surveyed as far west as present-day [[Little Rock, Arkansas|Little Rock]], while Robbins continued north to the [[Missouri River]]. Two trees near the site were blazed to mark the meeting point of the two survey lines. Although survey work based on this point continued in subsequent years, covering most of Arkansas, [[Missouri]], [[Minnesota]], [[Iowa]], and [[North Dakota|North]] and [[South Dakota]], the initial point was forgotten. It was rediscovered in 1921 by surveyors working the line between Phillips and Lee counties, who found the blazed trees. The [[Marianna, Arkansas]] chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution began a campaign to memorialize the spot, culminating in the placement of the stone marker and a dedication ceremony on October 27, 1926, the 111th anniversary of the point's establishment. One forgotten feature of the dedication ceremony was that four local landowners each gave deeds for {{convert|2|acre|ha}} of land surrounding the point, which would have created an eight-acre park. Arkansas designated the area as a state park in 1961, but appropriated no funds for land purchases or development. The Arkansas Natural Heritage Commission, recognizing the swamp's natural significance, provided funds to purchase the 37.5 acres which now make up the park. The Commission holds a conservation easement on the property to limit development. ==Gallery== {{gallery |width=296 |height=196 |lines=4 |Image:Louisiana Purchase State Park 003.jpg|Entrance to the park on [[Arkansas Highway 362|State Highway 362]]. |Image:Louisiana Purchase State Park 2015 3.JPG|Footpath leading to the boardwalk. |Image:Louisiana Purchase State Park 004.jpg|Boardwalk leading to the site. |Image:Louisiana Purchase State Park 008.jpg|Monument to the Louisiana Purchase Survey.}} ==See also== *[[List of Arkansas state parks]] *[[List of National Historic Landmarks in Arkansas]] *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in Lee County, Arkansas]] *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in Monroe County, Arkansas]] *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in Phillips County, Arkansas]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== ; Government *{{Official website|http://www.arkansasstateparks.com/louisianapurchase/}} ; General information *[http://www.encyclopediaofarkansas.net/encyclopedia/entry-detail.aspx?entryID=1237# Louisiana Purchase State Park] at ''[[Encyclopedia of Arkansas History & Culture]]'' {{Protected areas of Arkansas}} {{Subject bar|portal1=Arkansas|portal2=Geography|portal3=National Register of Historic Places|portal4=Sustainable development|portal5=War of 1812|portal6=Wetlands|commons=y|commons-search=Category:Louisiana Purchase State Park|d=y|d-search=Q1872230}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Louisiana Purchase Historic State Park}} [[Category:1961 establishments in Arkansas]] [[Category:Aftermath of the War of 1812 in the United States]] [[Category:Daughters of the American Revolution]] [[Category:Historic surveying landmarks in the United States]] [[Category:Landmarks of the War of 1812]] [[Category:Louisiana Purchase]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials on the National Register of Historic Places in Arkansas]] [[Category:National Historic Landmarks in Arkansas]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Lee County, Arkansas]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Monroe County, Arkansas]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Phillips County, Arkansas]] [[Category:Protected areas established in 1961]] [[Category:Protected areas of Lee County, Arkansas]] [[Category:Protected areas of Monroe County, Arkansas]] [[Category:Protected areas of Phillips County, Arkansas]] [[Category:State parks of Arkansas]]

{{Infobox recurring event |name = Minnesota Renaissance Festival |image = MinnRenaissanceFestCast2007-09-23.JPG |alt = |caption = Costumed participants at the 2007 Minnesota Renaissance Festival |location = [[Shakopee, Minnesota|Shakopee]], [[Minnesota]] {{Coord|44|44|47|N|93|35|56|W|region:US-MN_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |genre = Renaissance fair |first = 1971 |dates = August - September |attendance = 320,000 (average) |free_label = Stages |free_text = 16 |website = {{url|http://www.renaissancefest.com/}} }} '''The Minnesota Renaissance Festival''' is a [[Renaissance fair]], an interactive outdoor event which focuses on recreating the look and feel of a fictional 16th Century "England-like" fantasy kingdom.<ref>{{cite news |last=Ward|first=Bill| url=http://www.startribune.com/lifestyle/130587713.html | title=Don't look to Ren Fest for history lesson | work=Star Tribune | date=September 27, 2011 | accessdate=October 8, 2011}}</ref> It operates during weekends from mid-August until the final week in September on a site near the [[Minnesota River]] in [[Shakopee, Minnesota|Shakopee]], a suburb of the [[Minneapolis-Saint Paul|Twin Cities]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Ward|first=Bill| url=http://www.startribune.com/lifestyle/128827278.html | title=Fantasy meets reality at Renaissance Festival | work= Star Tribune| date=August 31, 2011 | accessdate=October 8, 2011}}</ref>
The Minnesota Renaissance Festival began in September 1971 on a {{convert|22|acre|m2|sing=on}} field in [[Jonathan, Minnesota]]. More than 25,000 people visited the two weekend grand opening of the festival then named “A Celebration of Nature, Art, and Life!” It was later moved to its current site in Shakopee where it continues as one of the oldest and largest Renaissance fairs in the United States. It has played host to the early careers of such national acts as the magicians [[Penn & Teller]] and [[The Flying Karamazov Brothers]] juggling troupe, and it currently hosts acts such as Zilch the Torysteller, [[Twig the Fairy]], Puke and Snot, Johnny Phoenix, The Tortuga Twins, The Danger Committee and Vilification Tennis.<ref>http://www.renaissancefest.com/entertainment.html</ref> On August 19, 1975, [[Penn & Teller]] did their first show together at the Minnesota Renaissance Festival.<ref>{{cite tweet|author=Jillette, Penn |author-link=Penn Jillette |user=pennjillette |number=104745893533716480 |date=August 19, 1975 |title=36 years ago today,Teller and I did our first show together at the Minnesota Renaissance Festival...}}</ref> [[Jason Mraz]] also worked as a pickle boy early in his performance career.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bream|first1=Jon|title=Mystic Lake lets Mr. Sunshine in|url=http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/music/124798254.html|work=Star Tribune|date=July 1, 2011}}</ref>
The festival features over 700 entertainers, 275 crafters, and 120 food booths.
The Minnesota Renaissance Festival is one of several such events in the [[United States]] owned and operated by Mid-America Festivals.
Because the land on which the festival was built is leased, in 2014 Mid-America Festivals announced that 2016 would likely be the last season in its current location. The lease contained a clause in which the owners could terminate the lease at any time. In 2016 Mid America Festivals announced the lease term would expire in 2019.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.renaissancefest.com/Assets/New%20Graphics%202016/Renaissance%20Lease%20Extended%20to%202019.pdf|title=Press Release: MN Renaissance Festival|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Minnesota Reanaissance Festival|access-date=August 19, 2016}}</ref> Currently, several sites are under consideration, including properties in other parts of Scott County and near Belle Plaine, Minnesota.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://belleplaineherald.com/Content/News/Local/Article/Renaissance-Festival-Eyeing-Possible-New-Home-Near-B-P-/7/39/5848|title=Renaissance Festival Eyeing Possible New Home Near B.P.|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=August 16, 2016}}</ref>
== Travel to the Festival ==
The Minnesota Renaissance Festival provides free parking at its site in Shakopee and directions from its website.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.renaissancefest.com/contact.html |title=Park and Directions - Minnesota Renaissance Festival}}</ref> Parking is available in two parking lots accessible by a single dirt road crossing active train tracks onto its 400 acre campus<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/twincities/blog/real_estate/2016/06/renaissance-festival-signs-lease-through-2019.html |title=Minnesota Renaissance Festival Signs New Lease}}</ref> Limited access to and from the festival site has led to significant transportation issues including delays as long as two hours either entering or leaving the fairgrounds.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.citypages.com/arts/dos-and-donts-of-the-minnesota-renaissance-festival-6579357 |title=Dos and Don'ts of the Minnesota Renaissance Festival}}</ref> Traffic problems have created significant backups and delays along Minnesota Highway 169<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.belleplaineherald.com/Content/News/Area-News/Article/Mid-America-Festivals-Buys-Land-for-Possible-Renaissance-Fest-Site/7/40/8536 |title=Mid-America Festivals Buys Land for Possible Renaissance Fest. Site}}</ref> with traffic being identified as the number one issue.<ref>{{citation |url=http://belleplaineherald.com/Content/News/Local/Article/Renaissance-Festival-Eyeing-Possible-New-Home-Near-B-P-/7/39/5848 |title= Renaissance Festival Eyeing Possible New Home Near B.P.}}</ref>
In the 1980s, the [[Minnesota Transportation Museum]] provided train trips to the Renaissance Festival using [[Northern Pacific 328]]. These trains used [[Chicago & North Western Railway]] tracks between Minneapolis and Merriam Junction, which is located next to the Renaissance Festival grounds. The rail line was severed between Hopkins and Chaska in 1991.
