{{Infobox military conflict | conflict = ROKS ''Cheonan'' sinking | partof = the [[Korean conflict]] | image = [[File:ROKS Cheonan salvaged debris.png|border|280px]] | caption = Four photos show damage to ROKS ''Cheonan'' — clockwise from upper left: (1) a damaged stack; (2) front portion (port side) showing the break point; (3) a large fragment is lifted from the sea; (4) water pressure marks on the hull bottom. | date = 26 March 2010 | place = Near [[Baengnyeong Island]], [[Yellow Sea]] | map_type = | map_caption = | latitude = | longitude = | result = Sinking of ROKS ''Cheonan'' under disputed circumstances * [[South Korea]]n-led investigation concluded that ''Cheonan'' was sunk by North Korean midget submarine * [[North Korea]] denies involvement | combatant1 = {{flagcountry|Republic of Korea}} * {{flagicon image|Naval Jack of South Korea.svg}} [[Republic of Korea Navy|ROK Navy]] | combatant2 = {{flagcountry|Democratic People's Republic of Korea}} (presumed) * {{flagicon image|Flag of the Korean People's Navy.svg}} [[Korean People's Navy]] (presumed) | commander1 = {{flagicon image|Naval Jack of South Korea.svg}} Commander Choi Won-il | commander2 = {{flagicon image|Flag of the Korean People's Navy.svg}} Unknown (presumed) | strength1 = 1 {{Sclass-|Pohang|corvette}} | strength2 = 1 {{Sclass2-|Yono|submarine}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid%3Dnewsarchive%26sid%3DaXd_gvnsSEQo%26pos%3D8 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=12 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150328224643/http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive |archivedate=28 March 2015 }} | casualties1 = 46 killed
56 wounded
{{ship|ROKS|Cheonan|PCC-772|6}} sunk | casualties2 = none | campaignbox = {{Naval engagements of the Korean War}} }} {{Infobox news event |title= |image= |caption= |date=26 March 2010 |time=21:22 [[Korea Standard Time]] |place= |also known as= |first reporter= |filmed by= |participants={{navy|Republic of Korea}} (ROK)
{{flagicon image|Flag of the Korean People's Navy.svg}} [[Korean People's Navy]] (DPRK) |reported property damage=1 ROKN corvette sunk, 46 personnel killed, 56 personnel wounded |inquiries=International investigation convened by ROK government, Russian Navy investigation |charges=ROK-convened (JIG) investigation concludes that DPRK sank the corvette using a midget submarine-launched torpedo.
Investigation results are disputed.
North Korea denies involvement. |convictions= |publication bans= |litigation= }} {{Infobox Korean name| hangul={{linktext|천안|함|피격|사건}} |hanja={{linktext|天安|艦|被擊|事件}} |rr=Cheonanham Pigyeok Sageon |mr=Ch'ŏnanham Pigyŏk Sagŏn }} The '''ROKS ''Cheonan'' sinking''' occurred on 26 March 2010, when {{ship|ROKS|Cheonan|PCC-772|2}}, a {{sclass-|Pohang|corvette}} of the [[Republic of Korea Navy]], carrying 104 personnel, sank off the country's west coast near [[Baengnyeong Island]] in the [[Yellow Sea]], killing 46 seamen. The cause of the sinking remains in dispute, although overwhelming evidence points to North Korea. A South Korean-led official investigation carried out by a team of international experts from South Korea, the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, and Sweden presented a summary of its investigation on 20 May 2010, concluding that the warship had been sunk by a [[North Korea]]n [[torpedo]]{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk00100&num=6392|title=Results Confirm North Korea Sank ''Cheonan''|publisher=Daily NK|accessdate=20 May 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100522235650/http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk00100&num=6392|archivedate=22 May 2010|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article7131533.ece|title='All out war' threatened over North Korea attack on warship ''Cheonan''|work=The Times|location=London|date=20 May 2010|accessdate=25 May 2010|first=Anne|last=Barrowclough}} fired by a [[midget submarine]]. The conclusions of the report resulted in significant controversy within South Korea. North Korea denied that it was responsible for the sinking.{{cite news|url=https://www.un.org/News/briefings/docs/2010/100615_Cheonan.doc.htm|title=Press Conference on Situation in Korean Peninsula: DPRK Permanent Representative to the United Nations Sin Son Ho|publisher=United Nations|work=Department of Public Information|date=15 June 2010|accessdate=11 July 2010}} North Korea's further offer to aid an open investigation was disregarded.Watson Paul (19 July 2012). [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/jul/19/korean-conflict-time-nuanced-view South Korea good, North Korea bad? Not a very useful outlook.] ''The Guardian''. Retrieved 26 December 2012. [[China]] dismissed the official scenario presented by South Korea and the United States as not credible. An investigation by the [[Russian Navy]] also did not concur with the report.{{cite news|url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_northkorea/432230.html|title=Russian Navy Expert Team's analysis on the ''Cheonan'' incident|publisher=The Hankyoreh|date=27 July 2010|accessdate=28 July 2010}} The [[United Nations Security Council]] made a [[Presidential Statement]] condemning the attack but without identifying the attacker.{{cite news|url=https://www.un.org/News/Press/docs/2010/sc9975.doc.htm|title=Presidential Statement: Attack on Republic of Korea Naval Ship 'Cheonan'|publisher=United Nations|work=United Nations Security Council|date=9 July 2010|id=S/PRST/2010/13|accessdate=11 July 2010}} ==Background== [[File:ROKS Cheonan sinking, location map.svg|thumb|right|The location of the sinking.]] {{Main article|North Korea – South Korea relations}} [[Baengnyeong Island]] is a [[South Korea]]n island in the [[Yellow Sea]], off the [[Ongjin, South Hwanghae|Ongjin]] peninsula in [[North Korea]]. It lies less than {{convert|10|mi|km}} from the North Korean coast, and is over {{convert|100|mi|km}} from the South Korean mainland. The island is to the south and west of the [[Northern Limit Line]], the ''de facto'' [[maritime boundary]] dividing South Korea (ROK) from [[North Korea]] (DPRK). [[File:Map of Korean maritime border.svg|thumb|left|The disputed maritime border between North and South Korea in the [[Yellow Sea|West Sea]]:Ryoo, Moo Bong. (2009). [http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?AD=ADA500904&Location=U2&doc=GetTRDoc.pdf "The Korean Armistice and the Islands,"] p. 13 (at [http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?AD=ADA500904&Location=U2&doc=GetTRDoc.pdf PDF-p. 21]). Strategy research project at the U.S. Army War College; retrieved 26 Nov 2010.
{{Color box|blue|border=darkgray}} '''A:''' United Nations-created Northern Limit Line, 1953[https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6AM2O820101123 "Factbox: What is the Korean Northern Limit Line?"] Reuters (UK). 23 November 2010; retrieved 26 Nov 2010.
{{Color box|red|border=darkgray}} '''B:''' North Korea-declared "Inter-Korean MDL", 1999Van Dyke, Jon ''et al.'' "The North/South Korea Boundary Dispute in the Yellow (West) Sea," ''Marine Policy'' 27 (2003), 143–158; note that "Inter-Korean MDL" is cited because it comes from an academic source, {{cite web|url=http://www.law.hawaii.edu/sites/www.law.hawaii.edu/files/webFM/Faculty/N-SKoreaBoundary2003.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-03-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309130908/http://www.law.hawaii.edu/sites/www.law.hawaii.edu/files/webFM/Faculty/N-SKoreaBoundary2003.pdf |archivedate= 9 March 2012 |df= }} (PDF), and the writers were particular enough to include in quotes as we present it. The broader point is that the maritime demarcation line here is NOT a formal extension of the Military Demarcation Line; compare [http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/200211/21/eng20021121_107188.shtml "NLL—Controversial Sea Border Between S.Korea, DPRK, "] ''People's Daily'' (PRC), 21 November 2002; retrieved 22 Dec 2010 The locations of specific islands are reflected in the configuration of each maritime boundary, including
1–[[Yeonpyeong Island]]
2–[[Baengnyeong Island]]
3–[[Daecheong Island]]
---- {{hidden begin|toggle=left|title=Other map features}}4-[[Jung-gu, Incheon|Jung-gu]] (Incheon Intl. Airport), 5-[[Seoul]], 6-[[Incheon]], 7-[[Haeju]], 8-[[Kaesong]], 9-[[Ganghwa County]], 10-Bukdo Myeon, 11-[[Deokjeokdo]], 12-Jawol Myeon, 13-Yeongheung Myeon{{hidden end}} ]] The area is the site of considerable tension between the two states; although it was provided in the [[armistice]] agreement for the [[stalemate]] of the [[Korean war]] that the islands themselves belonged to the South, the sea boundary was not covered by the [[armistice]], and the sea is claimed by the North. The situation is further complicated by the presence of a rich fishing ground used by DPRK and Chinese fishing vessels, and there have been [[Northern Limit Line#Incidents along the line|numerous clashes]] over the years between naval vessels from both sides attempting to police what both sides regard as their [[territorial waters]]. These have been referred to as "[[Northern Limit Line#Incidents along the line|crab wars]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/nll.htm|title=Northern Limit Line (NLL) West Sea Naval Engagements|publisher=globalsecurity.org|accessdate=31 March 2010}} ===History of ship sinkings on both sides=== In late May 2010, [[Bruce Cumings]], a [[University of Chicago]] expert on Korean affairs, commented that the sinking should be regarded as part of long-running tensions in a naval [["no-man's land"|no-man's land]]. He noted a [[Battle of Daecheong|confrontation in November 2009]] in which several North Korean sailors died, and an incident in 1999 when 30 North Koreans were killed and 70 wounded when their ship sank. In both incidents, the North Koreans were the first to open fire. In the 1999 incident the South Koreans escalated matters by initiating a campaign of boat 'bumping' in order to stop what the South saw as a violation of its maritime borders. Considering these previous incidents, Cumings said that the ''Cheonan'' sinking was "ripped out of context, the context of a continuing war that has never ended."{{cite web|url=http://www.democracynow.org/2010/5/27/nk|title=Historian Bruce Cumings: US Stance on Korea Ignores Tensions Rooted in 65-Year-Old Conflict; North Korea Sinking Could Be Response to November '09 South Korea Attack|publisher=Democracy Now!|date=27 May 2010|accessdate=26 November 2010}} ===Military concerns=== General [[Walter Sharp]], Commander of the South Korea-U.S. Combined Forces Command at the time had, on 24 March, testified before the [[United States House Committee on Appropriations|US House Appropriations Committee]], in part, on the need to strengthen the ROK-U.S. alliance, the need for on-site advanced training of the Air Force, the need to improve the quality of life and provide tour normalization for troops serving one-year tours, planned relocation of bases, and the scheduled 2012 transition of Operational Control (OPCON) to ROK hands. He also warned of the possibility that North Korea could "even launch an attack on the ROK."{{cite web|url=http://www.dod.mil/dodgc/olc/docs/testSharp04082011.pdf|title=See p. 12, STATEMENT OF GENERAL WALTER L. SHARP, COMMANDER, UNITED NATIONS COMMAND; COMMANDER, UNITED STATES-REPUBLIC OF KOREA COMBINED FORCES COMMAND; AND COMMANDER, UNITED STATES FORCES KOREA BEFORE THE SENATE / HOUSE ARMED SERVICES COMMITTEE HOUSE APPROPRIATIONS COMMITTEE MILCON SUBCOMMITTEE|last=|first=|date=24 March 2010|work=Committee on Appropriation, US House of Representatives|accessdate=28 November 2010}} ==Sinking of ''Cheonan''== [[File:TOD image for Cheonan ship of South Korean Navy.jpg|thumb|Thermal image of ''Cheonan'' sinking]] [[File:PCC-783.jpg|right|thumb|Another ''Pohang''-class corvette, ''Sinsung'']] On the night of the sinking, the U.S. and South Korean navies were engaged in joint anti-submarine warfare exercises 75 miles (121 km) away.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/washington/articles/2010/06/05/ap_enterprise_sub_attack_came_near_drill/ |title=AP Enterprise: Sub attack was near US-SKorea drill - Boston.com |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |date=5 June 2010 |publisher=[[New York Times Company|NYTC]] |location=[[Boston, MA|Boston]] |issn=0743-1791 |oclc=66652431 |accessdate=4 April 2014 |others=Jean H. Lee and Kwang-Tae Kim in Seoul contributed to this report. |first=Pauline |last=Jelinek |agency=Associated Press |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140405012126/http://www.boston.com/news/nation/washington/articles/2010/06/05/ap_enterprise_sub_attack_came_near_drill/ |archivedate= 5 April 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.military.com/news/article/sub-attack-came-near-drill.html |title='Sub Attack Came Near Drill' |work=military.com |date=5 June 2010 |accessdate=4 April 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100608033218/http://www.military.com/news/article/sub-attack-came-near-drill.html |archivedate=8 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |author=Associated Press}} This was part of the annual ''[[Key Resolve]]/[[Foal Eagle]]'' war exercise, described as "one of the world's largest simulated exercises", involving many U.S. and South Korean warships.{{cite news|url=http://www.marines.mil/unit/mcasiwakuni/Pages/2010/03/ExercisesKeyResolveFoalEagle2010kickoff.aspx|author=Lance Cpl. Claudio A. Martinez|title=Exercises Key Resolve/Foal Eagle 2010 kick off|date=11 March 2010|publisher=U.S. Marine Corps|accessdate=26 May 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605032051/http://www.marines.mil/unit/mcasiwakuni/Pages/2010/03/ExercisesKeyResolveFoalEagle2010kickoff.aspx|archivedate=2010-06-05}}{{cite news|url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Korea/LE05Dg01.html|author=Kim Myong Chol|title=Pyongyang sees US role in ''Cheonan'' sinking|date=5 May 2010|publisher=Asia Times Online|accessdate=26 May 2010}} On Friday, 26 March 2010, an explosion was reported to have occurred near {{ship|ROKS|Cheonan|PCC-772|2}}, a {{sclass-|Pohang|corvette}},{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/asiapcf/03/26/south.korea.ship.sinking/index.html|title=Report: South Korean navy ship sinks|accessdate=26 March 2010|publisher=CNN|date=27 March 2010}} near the [[stern]] of the ship at 9:22 pm''' '''[[UTC+9|local time]] (12:22 pm [[Greenwich Mean Time|GMT]]/[[coordinated universal time|UTC]]).{{cite news|publisher=[[Korea Times]]|title=Chronology of the ''Cheonan'' Sinking|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2010/04/116_65091.html|date=29 April 2010|accessdate=25 May 2010}} This caused the ship to break in half five minutes afterward, sinking at approximately 9:30 pm about {{convert|1|nmi|km}} off the south-west coast of [[Baengnyeong Island]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/8589507.stm|title=South Korean navy ship sinks near sea border with North|date=26 March 2010|publisher=BBC|accessdate=26 March 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/8596081.stm|title=Poor weather halts search of South Korea sunken warship|date=31 March 2010|publisher=BBC|accessdate=31 March 2010}} Some initial reports suggested that the ship was hit by a North Korean torpedo, and that the South Korean vessel had returned fire.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/warship-mystery-raises-korean-tensions-1928740.html|author=Kim Sengupta|title=Warship mystery raises Korean tensions|work=The Independent|location=London|date=27 March 2010}} However, the South Korean Ministry of Defense stressed in the first press briefings after the sinking that there was "no indication of North Korean involvement".{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8598267.stm|title=South Korea urges restraint over sunken warship|publisher=BBC News|date=1 April 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-03-27/south-korea-seeks-survivors-of-sunken-ship-north-korea-silent.html|title=Businessweek – Business News, Stock market & Financial Advice|work=Businessweek.com|accessdate=30 October 2014}} ''Cheonan'' was operating its [[active sonar]] at the time, which did not detect any nearby submarine. Several theories have subsequently been put forth by various agencies as to the cause of the sinking.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/01/opinion/01iht-edgregg.html?_r=2&ref=cheonan_ship|work=The New York Times|title=Testing North Korean Waters|first=Donald P.|last=Gregg|date=31 August 2010}} Early reports also suggested that South Korean navy units had shot at an unidentified ship heading towards North Korea, but a defense official later said that this target may have been a flock of birds misidentified on radar.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/mar/26/south-korea-navy-ship-attack|author=Tania Branigan and Caroline Davies|title=South Korean naval ship sinks in disputed area after 'explosion'|date=26 March 2010|work=The Guardian|location=London|accessdate=30 March 2010}} The ship had a crew of 104 men at the time of sinking, and 58 crewmembers were rescued by 11:13 pm local time. The remaining 46 crew died.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304370304575151463261442990|title=Divers Reach South Korean Wreckage|author=Evan Ramstad|date=29 March 2010|work=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=9 July 2010}} The stern of ''Cheonan'' settled on its left side in {{convert|430|ft|m|order=flip|adj=on}} deep water close to the site of the sinking, but the bow section took longer to sink and settled overturned in {{convert|66|ft|m|order=flip}} of water {{convert|6.4|km|nmi}} away with a small part of the hull visible above the water.{{cite news|url=http://www.msc.navy.mil/sealift/2010/May/Sealift-2010-05.pdf#page=3|title=Salvor supports recovery of South Korean navy ship|page=3|author=Edward Baxter|work=Sealift|publisher=Military Sealift Command, U.S. Navy|date=May 2010|accessdate=9 April 2012}} ==Rescue efforts== [[File:ROKS Cheonan salvage meeting.jpg|thumb|Vice Admiral Kim Jung Du, commander for the Republic of Korea Navy salvage efforts, and Rear Adm. [[Richard Landolt]], on scene commander of U.S. support to ROK salvage efforts, discuss salvage operations aboard the {{ship|ROKS|Dokdo}}]] Initially six South Korean navy and two South Korean coast guard ships assisted in the rescue as well as aircraft from the [[Republic of Korea Air Force]].{{cite news|url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/southkorea/7528520/South-Korea-investigates-whether-North-involved-in-ship-sinking.html|title=South Korea investigates whether North involved in ship sinking|first=Rob|last=Crilly|work=The Daily Telegraph|location=London|accessdate=26 March 2010|date=26 March 2010}} It was reported on March 27 that hopes of finding the 46 missing crew alive were fading. Survival time in the water was estimated at about two hours and large waves were hampering rescue attempts.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/8590515.stm|title=Hopes fading for South Korea sailors|work=BBC News|accessdate=27 March 2010|date=27 March 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2010/03/113_63157.html|title=More Questions Raised Than Answered Over Sunken Ship|first=Tae-hoon|last=Lee|date=28 March 2010|work=The Korea Times|accessdate=28 March 2010}} After the sinking, [[Lee Myung-bak|President Lee]] said that recovery of survivors was the main priority. Air was pumped into the ship to keep any survivors alive.[https://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20100327/wl_nm/us_korea_ship_12 South Korea rules out navy ship sunk by North Korea], Reuters, Jo Yonghak, 27 March 2010 Over 24 military vessels were involved over course of the search-and-rescue effort,{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/8592175.stm|title=Sunken section of South Korean naval vessel found|work=BBC News|accessdate=29 March 2010|date=29 March 2010}} including four U.S. Navy vessels: {{USNS|Salvor|T-ARS-52|6}}, {{USS|Harpers Ferry|LSD-49|6}}, {{USS|Curtis Wilbur|DDG 54|6}}, and {{USS|Shiloh|CG-67|6}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.pacom.mil/media/news/2010/04/20100406-US%20Support%20to%20ROK%20Salvage%20Ops.shtml |title=U.S. Support to ROK Salvage Operations Changes Leadership |publisher=Amphibious Force Seventh Fleet Public Affairs |date=4 April 2010 |accessdate=1 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140204012631/http://www.pacom.mil/media/news/2010/04/20100406-US%20Support%20to%20ROK%20Salvage%20Ops.shtml |archivedate=4 February 2014 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news|url=http://www.stripes.com/article.asp?section=104&article=69124|title=South Koreans hold out hope for sailors missing after ship explosion|work=Stars and Stripes|accessdate=3 April 2010}} On 30 March 2010 it was reported that one South Korean naval diver (ROKN UDT/SEAL CWO Han Ju-ho) had died after losing consciousness while searching for survivors, and another had been hospitalised.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/8594226.stm|title=Diver dies at South Korean warship rescue site|date=30 March 2010|work=BBC News|accessdate=30 March 2010}} On 3 April 2010, South Korean officials said that a private fishing boat involved in the rescue operations had collided with a [[Cambodia]]n freighter, sinking the fishing boat and killing at least two people, with seven reported missing. The same day, the Joint Chiefs of Staff of South Korea said that the body of one of the 46 missing sailors had been found.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8601540.stm|title=Nine missing as S Korean boat sinks in warship search|work=BBC News|date=3 April 2010|accessdate=3 April 2010}} Later on 3 April 2010 South Korea called off the rescue operation for the missing sailors, after families of the sailors asked for the operation to be suspended for fear of further casualties among the rescue divers. The military's focus then shifted towards salvage operations, which were predicted to take up to a month to complete.{{cite news|url= https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jQydsIWmNQZpwRriADac51u5rx8gD9ERMARG1|title=SKorea stops underwater search for missing sailors|author=Kwang-Tae Kim|date=3 April 2010|work=The Associated Press|accessdate=3 April 2010}} ==Recovery== [[File:US Navy 100409-N-9123L-002 Dive tenders recover divers aboard the Military Sealift Command rescue and salvage ship USNS Salvor (T-ARS 52).jpg|thumb|A South Korean and U.S. diver during the recovery phase]] [[File:ROKS Cheonan salvage and recovery site, toward island.jpg|thumb|The first, stern section, recovery site]] On 15 April 2010, the stern section of the ship was winched from the seabed by a large [[floating crane]], drained of water and placed on a barge for transportation to the [[Pyongtaek]] navy base.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8621418.stm|title=Stern of South Korea naval ship lifted from sea bed|work=BBC News|date=15 April 2010|accessdate=15 April 2010}} On 23 April 2010, the stack was recovered, and on 24 April the bow portion was raised.{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2010/04/116_64756.html|title=Front Half of ''Cheonan'' to Be Raised Today|first=Tae-hoon|last=Lee|date=23 April 2010|accessdate=25 May 2010}} The salvaged parts were taken to [[Pyongtaek]] navy base for an investigation into the cause of the sinking by both South Korean and foreign experts. The bodies of 40 personnel out of 46 who went down with the ship were recovered.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia-pacific/2010/04/201042912957232586.html|title=Asia-Pacific — Funeral held for S Korean sailors|publisher=Al Jazeera English|date=29 April 2010|accessdate=20 May 2010}} ==Cause of sinking== ===Investigation=== [[File:US Navy 100913-N-4366B-501 Rear Adm. Hyun Sung Um, commander of Republic of Korea (ROK) Navy 2nd Fleet, and Rear Adm. Seung Joon Lee, deputy comman.jpg|thumb|South Korean and US Navy admirals inspecting the wreckage of ''Cheonan'' at [[Pyeongtaek]] on 13 September 2010.]] After raising the ship, South Korea and the United States formed a joint investigative team to discover the cause of the sinking.{{cite web|url=http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=2918871|title=INSIDE JoongAng Daily|publisher=Joongangdaily.joins.com|date=7 April 2010|accessdate=20 May 2010}} Later South Korea announced that it intended to form an international group to investigate the sinking including Canada, Britain, Sweden and Australia.{{cite web|author=(AFP) – 12 Apr 2010|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gOgULd0mCVXkMrugSmJ6BIHhWmkQ|title=AFP: Australians to join probe into S.Korea warship sinking|publisher=Google |date=12 April 2010|accessdate=20 May 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.international.gc.ca/media/165.aspx?lang=eng|title=Canadian Naval Expertise to Assist in Multinational Investigation into the ''Cheonan'' Sinking|accessdate=16 May 2010|date=16 May 2010|publisher=[[Department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade|Foreign Affairs and International Trade Canada]]}} On 16 April 2010, Yoon Duk-yong, co-chairman of the investigation team, said "In an initial examination of ''Cheonan''{{'}}s stern, South Korean and U.S. investigators found no traces showing that the hull had been hit directly by a torpedo. Instead, we've found traces proving that a powerful explosion caused possibly by a torpedo had occurred underwater. The explosion might have created a bubble jet that eventually generated an enormous shock wave and caused the ship to break in two."{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/special/2010/04/180_64462.html|title=N. Korean Submarines Pose Grave Threat to Security|author=Jung Sung-ki|date=19 April 2010|publisher=Korea Times|location=Seoul|accessdate=25 April 2010}} Traces of an explosive chemical substance used in torpedoes, [[RDX]], were later found in May 2010.{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-05/10/c_13285608.htm|title=S. Korea confirms detection of explosive chemical in sunken warship|date=10 May 2010|publisher=Xinhua|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100522161652/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-05/10/c_13285608.htm|archivedate=22 May 2010|df=dmy-all}} ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported on 19 May 2010, that a team of investigators from Sweden, Australia, Britain, and the United States had concluded that a North Korean torpedo sank the ship. The team found that the torpedo used was identical to a North Korean torpedo previously captured by South Korea.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/05/18/AR2010051803094.html|title=South Korea to officially blame North Korea for March torpedo attack on warship|work=[[Washington Post]]|author=Pomfret, John|author2=Harden, Blaine |date=19 May 2010|accessdate=20 May 2010}} On 25 April 2010, the investigative team announced that the cause of the sinking was a non-contact underwater explosion.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk00100&num=6276|title=Cheonan Analysis Reveals Non-Contact Cause|publisher=Daily NK|date=26 April 2010|accessdate=20 May 2010}} On 7 May 2010, a government official said that a team of South Korean civilian and military experts[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/world/asia_pacific/10130309.stm Excerpts: South Korea ship sinking report], BBC, 20 May 2010 had found traces of [[RDX]], a high explosive more powerful than [[Trinitrotoluene|TNT]] and used in torpedoes.[http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2010/05/113_65519.html Explosives from torpedo found on sunken ship, by Lee Tae-hoon] [[Korea Times]], 7 May 2010 On 19 May 2010, the discovery of a fragment of metal containing a serial number similar to one on a North Korean torpedo salvaged by South Korea in 2003 was announced.{{cite web|url=http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=2920725|title=Probe IDs torpedo that sunk ''Cheonan'': sources|publisher=JoongAng Daily|date=20 May 2010|accessdate=20 May 2010}} In their summary for the [[United Nations Security Council]], the investigation group was described as the "Joint Civilian-Military Investigation Group of the Republic of Korea with the participation of international experts from Australia, Sweden, the United Kingdom and the United States, and the Multinational Combined Intelligence Task Force, comprising the Republic of Korea, Australia, Canada, the United Kingdom and the United States," which consisted of "25 experts from 10 top Korean expert agencies, 22 military experts, 3 experts recommended by the National Assembly, and 24 foreign experts constituting 4 support teams". ===Joint Civilian-Military Investigation Group (JIG) report=== ====Summary==== On 20 May the South Korean-led investigation group released a summary of their report{{cite web|url=http://www.mnd.go.kr/webmodule/htsboard/template/read/engbdread.jsp?typeID=16&boardid=88&seqno=871&c=TITLE&t=&pagenum=3&tableName=ENGBASIC&pc=undefined&dc=&wc=&lu=&vu=&iu=&du=&st=|title=Investigation Result on the Sinking of ROKS ''Cheonan'' – report statement|date=20 May 2010|publisher=Ministry of National Defense R.O.K.|at=News item No 592|accessdate=20 May 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130425143808/http://www.mnd.go.kr/webmodule/htsboard/template/read/engbdread.jsp?typeID=16&boardid=88&seqno=871&c=TITLE&t=&pagenum=3&tableName=ENGBASIC&pc=undefined&dc=&wc=&lu=&vu=&iu=&du=&st=|archivedate=25 April 2013|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mnd.go.kr/cms_file/popup_file/Result_movie_eng.wmv|title=Investigation Activities on the Sinking of ROKS "Cheonan" – investigation video|date=20 May 2010|publisher=Ministry of National Defense R.O.K.|at=Linked from news item No 592|accessdate=20 May 2010}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite report|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/nol/shared/bsp/hi/pdfs/20_05_10jigreport.pdf|title=Investigation Result on the Sinking of ROKS ''Cheonan'' – Press Summary|date=20 May 2010|work=The Joint Civilian-Military Investigation Group|publisher=Ministry of National Defense R.O.K. / BBC|accessdate=20 May 2010}} in which they concluded that the sinking of the warship was the result of a North Korean torpedo attack, commenting that "The evidence points overwhelmingly to the conclusion that the torpedo was fired by a North Korean submarine." The inquiry also alleged that a group of small submarines, escorted by a support ship, departed from a North Korean naval base a few days before the sinking.{{cite news|author=Adam Brookes|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/world/asia_pacific/10129703.stm|title='North Korean torpedo' sank South's navy ship — report|publisher=BBC News|date= 20 May 2010|accessdate=20 May 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/1261022/North-Korea-%27sank-South-Korean-ship%27|title=World News Australia — North Korea 'sank South Korean ship'|publisher=Sbs.com.au|accessdate=20 May 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/US/05/19/south.korea.ship/index.html?hpt=T1|title=North Korea denies sinking warship; South Korea vows strong response|publisher=CNN|date=20 May 2010|accessdate=20 May 2010}} The specific weapon used was alleged to be a North Korean manufactured [[CHT-02D torpedo]], of which substantial parts were recovered.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/7743830/North-Korea-condemned-by-world-powers-over-torpedo-attack.html|title=North Korea condemned by world powers over torpedo attack|publisher=The Telegraph|date=20 May 2010|accessdate=20 May 2010|location=London|first1=Peter|last1=Foster|first2=Malcolm|last2=Moore}} According to the ''[[Chosun Ilbo]]'', South Korean investigators told their journalists that they believe that one or two North Korean submarines, a {{sclass2-|Yono|submarine|1}} and the other a {{sclass2-|Sang-O|submarine|1}}, departed a naval base at Cape Bipagot accompanied by a support ship on 23 March 2010. One of the subs, according to the report, detoured around to the west side of [[Baengnyeong Island]], arriving on 25 March 2010. There, it waited about {{convert|30|m|ft}} under the ocean's surface in waters {{convert|40|to|50|m|ft}} deep for ''Cheonan'' to pass by. Investigators believe that the submarine fired the torpedo from about 3 km away. The attack appears to have been timed for a period when tidal forces in the area were slow. The North Korean vessels returned to port on 28 March 2010.{{cite news|publisher=[[Chosun Ilbo]]|title=How Did N. Korea Sink The ''Cheonan''?|url=http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2010/05/21/2010052100698.html|date=21 May 2010|accessdate=21 May 2010}} Such detailed information on the North Korean submarine movements, and attack position, was not in the official summary or final report. [[File:CHT-02D torpedo propulsion section showing 1번 marking.jpg|thumb|CHT-02D torpedo propulsion section showing 1번 marking]] The torpedo parts recovered at the site of the explosion by a dredging ship on 15 May which include the 5×5 bladed contra-rotating propellers, propulsion motor and a steering section, was claimed to match the schematics of the CHT-02D torpedo included in introductory brochures provided to foreign countries by North Korea for export purposes. An incorrect, though similar, torpedo schematic had by mistake been shown at the televised RIG briefing for comparison with the recovered parts.{{cite news|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/national/2010/06/29/49/0301000000AEN20100629007300315F.HTML|title=Investigators admit using wrong blueprint to show N. Korean torpedo that attacked ''Cheonan''|author=Kim Deok-hyun|date=29 June 2010|publisher=Yonhap|accessdate=2 August 2010}} The correct schematic has never been made public. The markings in [[Hangul]], which reads "1번" (or No. 1 in English), found inside the end of the propulsion section, is consistent with the marking of a previously obtained North Korean torpedo, but inconsistent with one found seven years ago, which is marked "4호."{{cite news|url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/421856.html|title=Questions raised following ''Cheonan'' announcement|publisher=The Hankyoreh| date=21 May 2010| accessdate=8 July 2010}} Critics have pointed out that '호" is the term used most often in the North, rather than "번." Russian and Chinese torpedoes are marked in their respective languages. The CHT-02D torpedo manufactured by North Korea utilizes acoustic/wake homing and passive acoustic tracking methods. Simulations indicated that {{convert|250|kg|lb|abbr=on}} of [[TNT equivalent]] explosive at {{convert|6|to|9|m|ft}} depth, {{convert|3|m|ft}} to the port of the center line, would result in the damage seen to ''Cheonan''.{{cite web|url=http://mnd-policy.tistory.com/353|title="Smoking Gun" Briefing Slides|work=South Korean Ministry of Defense|date=20 May 2010|accessdate=31 July 2010}} ([http://www.armscontrolwonk.com/files/MND_slides.pdf PDF version of partial slide set]) The full report had not been released to the public at this time,{{cite news|title=South Korea's Case for How the ''Cheonan'' Sank|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2010455,00.html|work=Time|accessdate=15 August 2010|date=13 August 2010|first=Bill|last=Powell}} though the South Korean legislature was provided with a five-page synopsis of the report. ====Full report==== A draft copy of the report was obtained by [[Time (magazine)|''Time'' magazine]] in early August 2010, before the final report was released. According to ''Time'', the report assessed in detail ten possible alternative scenarios, with extensive discussion and explanation of why those ten were not possible. It finally settled on the eleventh explanation, which was a North Korean attack, which it said was a "high possibility." In support of this conclusion, the report says that witnesses had reported seeing flashes of light or sounds of an explosion, as well as that the [[US Navy]] analysis of the wreck concluded that a torpedo containing 250 kilograms of explosives had collided with ''Cheonan'' six to nine meters below the waterline. Damage to the hull supported this conclusion, while inconsistent with what would be expected if the ship had run aground or had been hit with a missile. On 13 September 2010, the full report was released.{{citation|url=http://www.nautilus.org/publications/essays/napsnet/sr/Cheonan.pdf |title=Joint Investigation Report On the Attack Against the ROKS Ship ''Cheonan'' |work=Ministry of National Defense of the Republic of Korea |date=September 2010 |isbn=978-89-7677-711-9 |oclc=868822578 |accessdate=4 December 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111016214912/http://www.nautilus.org/publications/essays/napsnet/reports/Cheonan.pdf |archivedate=16 October 2011}} It concluded that ''Cheonan'' had been sunk due to a torpedo explosion, which, while not having contacted the ship, exploded several meters from the hull of the ship and caused a shockwave and bubble effect of sufficient strength to severely damage and sink the ship.{{cite web|title=Seoul reaffirms N. Korea's torpedo attack in final report|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2010/09/205_72997.html|publisher=Korea Times|accessdate=14 September 2010|date=13 September 2010}} [[File:CHT-02D torpedo wreckage on display at the War Memorial of Korea, 23 March 2011.jpg|thumb|CHT-02D torpedo wreckage on display at the [[War Memorial of Korea]], 23 March 2011]] ===South Korean opinions=== According to a survey conducted by Seoul National University's Institute for Peace and Unification Studies, less than one third of South Koreans trust the findings of the multinational panel.{{cite web|url=http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2010/09/08/2010090800979.html|title=The Chosun Ilbo (English Edition): Daily News from Korea – Most S.Koreans Skeptical About Cheonan Findings, Survey Shows|publisher=|accessdate=30 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.stripes.com/news/study-many-south-koreans-are-skeptical-of-investigators-report-on-cheonan-sinking-1.117603|title=Study: Many South Koreans are skeptical of investigators’ report on Cheonan sinking|work=Stars and Stripes|accessdate=30 October 2014}} A later survey by the JoongAng Ilbo newspaper in 2011 found that 68 percent of South Koreans trusted the government's report that ''Cheonan'' was sunk by a North Korean submersible.{{cite news|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2933766|title=1 year later, Cheonan still unresolved|author=Christine Kim|newspaper=JoongAng Daily|date=22 March 2011|accessdate=7 March 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130606172426/http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2933766|archivedate=6 June 2013|df=dmy-all}} Lee Jung Hee, a lawmaker with the opposition [[Democratic Labor Party (South Korea)|Democratic Labor Party]], was sued for defamation by seven people at South Korea's Joint Chiefs of Staff. Lee said during a speech in the national assembly that while the Defense Ministry had said there was no feed from a thermal observation device showing the moment the warship's stern and bow split apart, such a video did exist. Prosecutors then questioned Shin Sang-cheol, who served on the panel that investigated the incident and also runs Seoprise, over his assertion that ''Cheonan'' sank in an accident{{cite web|url=http://www.seoprise.com/~bu/dk/Letter_to_Hillary_Clinton_US_Secretary_of_State.pdf|title=Opinion about Accident of PCC-772|author=S. C. Shin|publisher=Seoprise|date=26 May 2010|accessdate=8 July 2010}} ([http://www.seoprise.com/board/view_nw.php?uid=154337&table=seoprise_12 HTML version]) and that the evidence linking the North to the torpedo was tampered with. The Defense Ministry asked the National Assembly to eject Shin from the panel for "arousing public mistrust."{{cite news|url=http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=2921120|title=Probe member summoned on false rumor allegations|author=Ser Myo-ja|date=20 May 2010|publisher=JoongAng Daily|accessdate=8 July 2010}}[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aXd_gvnsSEQo&pos=8 South Korea Faces Domestic Skeptics Over Evidence Against North], by Ben Richardson and Saeromi Shin, Bloomberg News, 30 May 2010 Shin stated that he doubted the official conclusion on the sinking, saying that when he looked at the dead sailors' bodies, they bore no signs of an explosion.{{cite news|author=Barbara Demick and John M. Glionna|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jul/23/world/la-fg-korea-torpedo-20100724|title=Doubts surface on North Korea's role in ship sinking|work=Los Angeles Times|date=23 July 2010|accessdate=24 July 2010}} Shin wrote a letter addressed to US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton showing the evidence for his contention that the ship ran aground and then collided with another vessel.{{cite news|url=http://www.seoprise.com/board/view.php?table=seoprise_12&uid=154146 |title=Letter to Hillary Clinton, U.S. Secretary of State |publisher=Seoprise.com |date=26 May 2010 |accessdate=1 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524045335/http://www.seoprise.com/board/view.php?table=seoprise_12&uid=154146 |archivedate=24 May 2011 }} ===Russian Navy experts assessment=== [[File:Rear Screw Hub Face (DSC 0698).jpg|thumb|Rear of the torpedo, with a [[Bivalve shell|clamshell fragment]] inside one of screw hub holes{{cite news|url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_northkorea/447266.html|title=Clamshell covered in white substance discovered on Cheonan torpedo fragment|author=Kwon Hyuk-chul|newspaper=The Hankyoreh|date=5 November 2010|accessdate=7 March 2012}}]] Near the end of May a team of [[Russian Navy]] submarine and torpedo experts visited South Korea to conduct an assessment of the South Korean led investigation. The team returned to Russia with samples for further physical-chemical analysis.{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/russia/20100608/159349260.html|title=Russian experts inspect to probe ''Cheonan'' issue at home|publisher=RIA Novosti|date=8 June 2010|accessdate=23 July 2010}} No official statement on the assessment has been made. It was claimed that the assessment concluded ''Cheonan'' was not sunk by a North Korean bubble jet torpedo, but did not come to any firm conclusion about the cause of the sinking.{{cite news|url=http://english.hani.co.kr/popups/print.hani?ksn=429769|title=Government protests Russia's Conflicting ''Cheonan'' findings|author=Lee Yeong-in|publisher=[[The Hankyoreh]]|date=10 July 2010|accessdate=23 July 2010}} ''[[The Hindu]]'' quoted a Russian Navy source stating that "after examining the available evidence and the ship wreckage Russian experts came to the conclusion that a number of arguments produced by the international investigation in favour of the DPRK's involvement in the corvette sinking were not weighty enough”.{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/article450117.ece|title=Russian probe undercuts ''Cheonan'' sinking theory|author=Vladimir Radyuhin|work=The Hindu |date=9 June 2010|accessdate=23 July 2010|location=Chennai, India}} On 27 July 2010, ''[[The Hankyoreh]]'' published what it claimed was a detailed summary of the Russian Navy expert team's analysis. According to ''The Hankyoreh'', the Russian investigators concluded that ''Cheonan'' touched the sea floor and damaged one of its propellers prior to a non-contact explosion, possibly caused by setting off a mine while the ship was trying to maneuver into deeper water. Visual examination of the torpedo parts South Korea found purportedly indicated that it had been in the water for more than 6 months.{{cite news|url=http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/ISSUE/75/432232.html|title=Russia's ''Cheonan'' investigation suspects that the sinking ''Cheonan'' ship was caused by a mine in water|publisher=The Hankyoreh|date=27 July 2010|accessdate=28 July 2010}} On the following day South Korean officials responded with "a full-scale refutation".{{cite news|url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/432422.html|title=Lee administration responds to Russian investigation report|publisher=The Hankyoreh|date=28 July 2010|accessdate=28 July 2010}} On 3 August 2010 Russian UN ambassador [[Vitaly Churkin]] stated that his country's investigative report's conclusions into the sinking would not be made public.''[[Yonhap]]'', "Moscow Not To Make Public Probe Outcome On ''Cheonan''{{'}}s Sinking: Amb. Churkin", 5 August 2010. Withholding the investigation results was seen as insensitive by South Korea, but avoided political damage to a number of states.{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2010/10/113_74440.html|title=Why Russia doesn't share its Cheonan results with Seoul|author=Sunny Lee|date=12 October 2010|publisher=Korea Times|location=Seoul|accessdate=10 March 2012}} ===Chinese claims=== During talks between the American and Chinese governments in late May 2010, Chinese officials were reported by [[Yoichi Shimatsu]], a commentator for the Chinese state-run [[CCTV-9]], to have claimed that the sinking of ''Cheonan'' had been as a result of an American [[naval mine|rising mine]], which was moored to the seabed and propels itself into a ship detected by sound or magnetics, planted during anti-submarine exercises that were conducted by the South Korean and US navies shortly before the sinking. To back up their claims, the Chinese said that North Korean submarines such as the one believed to have sunk ''Cheonan'' were incapable of moving undetected within South Korean waters, and a rising mine would have damaged the ship by splitting the hull, as was done to ''Cheonan'', rather than simply holing the vessel as a conventional torpedo does. A conventional torpedo traveling at {{convert|40|–|50|kn}} would also be completely destroyed upon impact, which was claimed to contradict the torpedo parts found later. (The original report, however, did not assert that a conventional torpedo strike had occurred, but rather that the torpedo had exploded underneath the ship, thus breaking its back. See above under '''Investigation'''.) {{cite web|url=http://newamericamedia.org/2010/05/did-an-american-mine-sink-the-south-korean-ship.php|title=Did an American Mine Sink South Korean Ship?|author=Yoichi Shimatsu,|publisher=New America Media|date=27 May 2010|accessdate=5 June 2010}} ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' journalist [[Peter Foster (journalist)|Peter Foster]] in a blog post noted that while not everyone (including Russia and China) was convinced of the truth of the [[ROKS Cheonan sinking#Cause of sinking|international inquiry into the ROKS ''Cheonan'' sinking]], some conspiracy theories and unanswered questions on the sinking, including one ascribing responsibility of the sinking to a rising mine deployed during a joint US-South Korean Foal Eagle anti-submarine exercises, ought to be read "with a large pinch of salt."{{cite news|title=Cheonan sinking: top ten conspiracy theories| url=http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/news/peterfoster/100042229/cheonan-sinking-top-ten-conspiracy-theories/| newspaper=The Daily Telegraph | location=London| date=4 June 2010}} ===Other international research=== A separate investigation conducted by scientists at the [[University of Manitoba]] yielded results that conflict with the official investigation's findings. According to the leader of the investigation, residue on the hull of the ship that was claimed to have been [[aluminum oxide]], which is a byproduct of explosions such as that of a torpedo, had a far higher ratio of oxygen to aluminum, leading the researchers to conclude that "we cannot say that the substance adhering to the ''Cheonan'' was the explosion byproduct of aluminum oxide."{{cite news|url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/427801.html|title=Scientists question ''Cheonan'' investigation findings|publisher=The Hankyoreh|date=28 June 2010|accessdate=29 June 2010}} The South Korean Ministry of Defense issued a rebuttal to the findings, saying, "The detonation of explosives containing aluminum occurs within hundreds of thousandths of a second under high temperatures of more than 3,000 degrees Celsius and high pressures of more than 200,000 atm, and most of it becomes noncrystalline aluminum oxide." A report published online by ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' on 8 July 2010 noted several instances of groups or individuals disagreeing with the official report.{{cite web|url=http://www.nature.com/news/2010/100708/full/news.2010.343.html|title=Controversy over South Korea's sunken ship|publisher=Nature|date=8 July 2010|accessdate=9 July 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://nautilus.org/napsnet/napsnet-policy-forum/rush-to-judgment-inconsistencies-in-south-koreas-cheonan-report/|title=Rush to Judgment: Inconsistencies in South Korea's Cheonan Report|author=Seunghun Lee and J.J. Suh|publisher=Nautilus Institute for Security and Sustainability|id=Policy Forum 10-039|date=15 July 2010|accessdate=24 July 2012}} The article also notes the rebuttal of those disagreements by analysts and government officials, with one analyst arguing that the sinking was "consistent with North Korea's behaviour in the past." In 2013, an academic paper was published analysing the available seismic data. It calculated that the sesmic data recorded would be accounted for by a {{convert|136|kg|lb|abbr=on}} TNT-equivalent charge, similar to the explosive yield of land control mines which had been abandoned in the vicinity.{{cite journal |url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs00024-012-0554-9 |title=Underwater Explosion (UWE) Analysis of the ROKS Cheonan Incident |author=So Gu Kim, Yefim Gitterman |journal=Pure and Applied Geophysics |volume=170 |issue=4 |date=10 August 2012 |doi=10.1007/s00024-012-0554-9 |issn=0033-4553 |accessdate=5 February 2015}}{{cite news |url=http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_northkorea/551681.html |title=New evidence that Cheonan was sunk by an old mine |author=Kang Tae-Ho |newspaper=Hankyoreh |date=14 September 2012 |accessdate=6 February 2015}} In 2014, an academic paper was published analysing the spectra of the seismic signals and hydroacoustic reverberation waves generated. The paper found it doubtful that the vibrations of the water column were caused by an underwater explosion, instead finding that the recorded seismic spectra were consistent with the natural vibration frequencies of a large submarine with a length of around {{convert|113|m|ft}}. This raised the possibility that the sinking was caused by a collision with a large submarine, rather than an explosion.{{cite journal |url=http://www.hindawi.com/journals/aav/2014/514346/ |title=What Really Caused the ROKS Cheonan Warship Sinking? |author=Hwang Su Kim and Mauro Caresta |journal=Advances in Acoustics and Vibration |date=20 November 2014 |doi=10.1155/2014/514346 |accessdate=5 February 2015}} ==Reaction== {{History of North Korea}} === South Korea === [[President of South Korea|South Korean President]] [[Lee Myung-bak]] convened an emergency meeting of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Orders were given to the military to concentrate on rescuing the survivors. In [[Seoul]], police were put on alert. At the time, a spokesman for the South Korean military stated that there was no evidence that [[North Korea]] had been involved in the incident. A large group of relatives of the missing sailors protested outside the navy base at [[Pyeongtaek]] over the lack of information provided to them. On 28 March relatives were taken to the site of the sunken vessel. Some relatives stated that survivors had claimed that the ''Cheonan'' had been in a poor state of repair.{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jQydsIWmNQZpwRriADac51u5rx8gD9ENJ9B83|title=Angry families visit site of sunken SKorean ship|author=Mark TranSi-Young Lee and Hyung-Jin Kim|date=28 March 2010|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=28 March 2010}} The Korean media have raised the issue of why the sister ship {{ship|ROKS|Sokcho|PCC778|2}}, which was operating nearby, did not come to the rescue of the sinking ship but instead fired shots at radar images which were later confirmed to be migratory birds.{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/opinon/2010/04/137_63498.html|title=Military Under Fire – Questions Grow Over Crisis Management Capability|date=1 April 2010|publisher=Korea Times|location=Seoul|accessdate=2 April 2010}} On 5 April 2010, President Lee Myung-bak visited Baengnyeong Island. He reiterated that it was risky to speculate over the cause, and the joint military and civilian investigation team would determine the cause. He said, "We have to find the cause in a way that satisfies not only our people but also the international community".{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2010/04/113_63696.html|title=Lee Warns Against Speculation Over ''Cheonan''|author=Na Jeong-ju|date=5 April 2010|publisher=Korea Times|location=Seoul|accessdate=5 April 2010}} The president of South Korea has mourned the victims and said that he will respond "resolutely" to the sinking without yet laying blame for its cause.{{cite news|title=South Korea mourns victims of ship sinking|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8643374.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=26 April 2010}} On 24 May Lee Myung-bak said the South would "resort to measures of self-defense in case of further military provocation of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea." He also supported readopting the official description of the North as the "main enemy."{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-05/25/c_13314888.htm|title=ROK president gives nod to calling DPRK "main enemy"|publisher=|accessdate=30 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131119020347/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-05/25/c_13314888.htm|archivedate=19 November 2013|df=dmy-all}} South Korea pursued measures from the [[United Nations Security Council]] after the incident, although the language used in the country's statements towards such measures became progressively weaker. In announcements made soon after the sinking, the government said that any draft presented by South Korea would explicitly state that North Korea was responsible for the incident, but by early July, the language had been reduced to only referring to "those responsible," in response to concerns from Russia.{{cite web|url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/428559.html|title=Requested Security Council ''Cheonan'' measures weaken considerably|publisher=The Hankyoreh|date=2 July 2010|accessdate=2 July 2010}} ====Diplomatic==== Since the incident, the South Korean government has been reluctant to engage in further diplomacy with North Korea over disputes such as North Korea's [[North Korea and weapons of mass destruction|nuclear weapons program]]. In response to a request by China, in April 2011 South Korea agreed to talks, but South Korean government officials commented that an apology from North Korea for the sinking would probably be necessary to facilitate any significant progress in the dialogues.''[[The Korea Herald]]'', "Seoul Insists On N. Korea Apology Before Dialogue", 18 April 2011; ''[[Yonhap]]'', "Seoul Renews Demand For N. Korea's Responsible Steps Over Deadly Attacks", 18 April 2011. ====Military==== On 2 May it was reported that South Korea's naval minister vowed "retaliation" against those responsible.{{cite news|title=S. Korea minister vows retaliation over warship sinking|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/restofasia/S-Korea-minister-vows-retaliation-over-warship-sinking/Article1-538274.aspx|work=Hindustan Times|date=2 May 2010|accessdate=2 May 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100505141833/http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/restofasia/S-Korea-minister-vows-retaliation-over-warship-sinking/Article1-538274.aspx|archivedate=5 May 2010|df=dmy-all}} Admiral Kim Sung-chan, at a publicly televised funeral for ''Cheonan''{{'}}s dead crew members in Pyeongtaek, stated that, "We will not sit back and watch whoever caused this pain for our people. We will hunt them down and make them pay a bigger price."''[[The Korea Herald]]'', "Navy Chief Vows Revenge For ''Cheonan''", 30 April 2010. On 4 May President Lee proposed "extensive reformations" for the South Korean military regarding the sinking incident.{{cite news|first=대우 (Dae-u)|last=김 (Kim)|script-title=ko:"작전,무기,군대조직,문화도 다바꿔라" 軍 전방위 개혁 예고|date=4 May 2010|url =http://biz.heraldm.com/common/Detail.jsp?newsMLId=20100504000486|work=Herald Economics|accessdate=5 May 2010|language=Korean|trans-title="Change All Of Plans, Weapons, Organization, Culture" Military Announces Omni-directional Reform}} After the official report was released South Korea has said that it will take strong countermeasures against the North.{{cite news|title=North Korea accused of sinking ship|date=20 May 2010|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/world/asia/3721583/North-Korea-accused-of-sinking-ship|accessdate=20 May 2010}} ====Trade==== On 24 May 2010, South Korea announced it would stop nearly all its trade with North Korea as a result of the official report blaming North Korea for the sinking. South Korea also announced it would prohibit North Korean vessels from using its shipping channels.{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/south-korea-cuts-trade-ties-with-north-over-sinking-20100524-w7y6.html|title=South Korea cuts trade ties with North over sinking|last=Choe Sang-Hun|date=24 May 2010|work=The Age|accessdate=24 May 2010|location=Melbourne, Australia}} According to the ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'', the trade embargoes were "the most serious action" South Korea could take short of military action.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/25/world/asia/25korea.html?ref=world|title=Pentagon and U.N. Chief Put New Pressure on N. Korea|last=Choe Sang-Hun|author2=Shanker, Thom |date=24 May 2010|work=New York Times|accessdate=24 May 2010}} The United States openly supported South Korea's decision.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article7134810.ece|title=South Korea bans all trade with North over ''Cheonan'' attack|last=Lewis|first=Leo|date=24 May 2010|work=The Times|location=London|accessdate=24 May 2010 }} The embargo is expected to cost the North Korean economy roughly $200 million a year.{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100524/ap_on_re_as/as_skorea_ship_sinks |title=US backs South Korea in punishing North Korea |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date=26 March 2010 |accessdate=25 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100526012553/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100524/ap_on_re_as/as_skorea_ship_sinks |archivedate=26 May 2010 }} The decision to cease trade was followed up with the United States and South Korea announcing they would conduct joint naval exercises in response to the sinking.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/world/asia_pacific/10150379.stm|title=US to conduct naval training exercises with S Korea after attack|date=24 May 2010|work=BBC News|publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=24 May 2010}} ====Psychological warfare==== The South Korean military announced that it would resume [[psychological warfare]] directed at North Korea. This would include both loudspeaker and [[FM radio]] propaganda broadcasts across the [[Korean Demilitarized Zone]] (DMZ). Meanwhile, a North Korean military commander stated, “If South Korea establishes new psychological warfare services, we will fire against them in order to eliminate them,” according to a report carried by the [[Korean Central News Agency]] (KCNA).{{cite news|url=http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk00100&num=6406|title=Psychological Warfare Will Resume|last=Kim So Yeol|date=24 May 2010|work=[[Daily NK]]|accessdate=24 May 2010}} South Korea began propaganda broadcasts into North Korea by radio on 25 May. North Korea responded by putting its troops on high alert, and severed most remaining ties and communications with South Korea in response to what it called a "smear campaign" by Seoul.{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/on_re_as/as_korea_ship_sinks |accessdate=25 May 2010 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} South Korean military propaganda FM broadcasts were resumed at 18:00 (local time) starting with the song "HuH" by [[K-pop]] band [[4minute]].{{cite web|url=http://www.allkpop.com/2010/05/south-korea-starts-border-propaganda-war-with-4minute|title=South Korea resumes border propaganda broadcast with 4minute!|publisher=|accessdate=30 October 2014}} As part of the propaganda broadcasts, South Korea reinstalled loudspeakers at eleven places along the DMZ. There was originally a plan to also use electronic signs, although due to cost, the plan was reportedly being reconsidered. On 13 June, South Korean media announced that the South Korean Defense Minister, Kim Tae-young, had said that anti-North Korea broadcasts were planned to resume after the [[United Nations Security Council]] took action against North Korea in response to the sinking of ''Cheonan''.{{cite news|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/northkorea/2010/06/13/3/0401000000AEN20100613003100315F.HTML|title=S. Korea reconsiders installing electronic signboards against N. Korea|date=13 June 2010|work=Yonhap|accessdate=14 June 2010}} ====Suppressing internal dissent==== Discourse over the events leading to the sinking of ''Cheonan'' was tightly controlled by the South Korean government in the months after the incident. On 8 May 2010, a former [[Senior Presidential Secretary|senior presidential secretary]] who served under Roh Moo-hyun, Park Seon-won,Korean newspapers have [[romanized]] his name as ''Park Seon-won''; however, papers he published while as a [[visiting fellow]] at the [[Brookings Institution]] indicate he romanizes his name as ''Sun-won Park''. was charged with [[libel]] by South Korea's Defense Minister, Kim Tae-young, over comments he made during a 22 April interview on [[Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation|MBC]] radio asking for greater disclosure from the military and government. Park Seon-won's response to the charge was: "I asked for the disclosure of information for a transparent and impartial investigation into the cause of the ''Cheonan'' sinking;" he added that "the libel suit seeks to silence public suspicion over the incident."{{cite news|title=Ex-Pres. Secretary Sued for Spreading ''Cheonan'' Rumors|date=8 May 2010|url=http://english.donga.com/srv/service.php3?bicode=040000&biid=2010050896608|accessdate=25 May 2010}} South Korea's Minister of Public Administration and Security, Maeng Hyung-kyu, announced on 20 May 2010 that the government was stepping up efforts to prosecute people who spread "groundless rumors" over the internet: "Anyone who makes false reports or articles about the incident could seriously damage national security. We will not let these be the basis of any risks the nation faces." Moreover, he announced the government would step up efforts to prevent "illegal gatherings" regarding the sinking of ''Cheonan''.{{cite news|title=Gov't warns against 'groundless rumors'|date=20 May 2010|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2010/05/117_66222.html|accessdate=25 May 2010}} A South Korean military oversight board, the Board of Inspection and Audit, has accused senior South Korean naval leaders of lying and hiding information. Said the board, "Military officers deliberately left out or distorted key information in their report to senior officials and the public because they wanted to avoid being held to account for being unprepared." In 2013, a documentary film named ''Project Cheonan Ship'' was released in South Korea about the sinking, including a number of possible alternative causes for the sinking. Members and relatives of the South Korean navy sought a court injunction to block the film’s release on the basis that the film distorted the facts. The injunction was denied in court, however, a major cimema chain, [[Megabox (movie theatres)|Megabox]], withdrew the film after warnings from conservative groups that they planned to picket showings the film.{{cite web |url=http://www.indexoncensorship.org/2013/09/project-cheonan-ship-steve-borowiec/ |title=South Korea: Film raises questions about Cheonan sinking |publisher=Index on Censorship |date=17 September 2013 |accessdate=6 February 2015}}{{cite news |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/korearealtime/2013/09/05/film-about-korean-sunken-ship-opens-in-theaters/ |title=Controversial Film About Warship Sinking Opens in Theaters |author=Jeyup S. Kwaak |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |date=5 September 2013 |accessdate=6 February 2015}} ===North Korea=== North Korea's [[Korean Central News Agency]] (KCNA) released an official response to the investigation on 28 May 2010, asserting, amongst other things, that it is unbelievable that part of a torpedo doing so much damage to a ship would survive:
Besides, the assertion that the screw shaft and engine remained undamaged and unchanged in shape is also a laughing shock. Even U.S. and British members of the international investigation team, which had blindly backed the South Korean regime in its 'investigation', were perplexed at the exhibit in a glass box.{{cite web|url=http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2010/201005/news28/20100528-18ee.html|title=Military Commentator on Truth behind "Story of Attack by North"|publisher=(North) Korean News|accessdate=28 May 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130218140842/http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2010/201005/news28/20100528-18ee.html|archivedate=18 February 2013|df=dmy-all}}
On 17 April 2010, it was reported that North Korea officially denied having had anything to do with the sinking, responding to what it referred to as "The puppet military warmongers, right-wing conservative politicians and the group of other traitors in South Korea".{{cite news|author=Miyoung Kim|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE63G0CN20100417|title=North Korea denies it sank South's navy ship|publisher=Reuters|date=17 April 2010|accessdate=20 May 2010}} An article from KCNA entitled "Military Commentator Denies Involvement in Ship Sinking" stated that the event was an accident.
... we have so far regarded the accident as a regretful accident that should not happen in the light of the fact that many missing persons and most of rescued members of the crew are fellow countrymen forced to live a tiresome life in the puppet army."[http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2010/201004/news17/20100417-15ee.html Military Commentator Denies Involvement in Ship Sinking ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100511090436/http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2010/201004/news17/20100417-15ee.html |date=11 May 2010 }}", ''[[Korean Central News Agency]]''. 17 April 2010. Retrieved 28 April 2010.
On 21 May 2010, North Korea offered to send their own investigative team to review the evidence compiled by South Korea,''[[The Hankyoreh]]'', "N. Korea's Reinvestigation Proposal Alters ''Cheonan'' Situation", 21 May 2010. and [[the Hankyoreh]] quoted Kim Yeon-chul, professor of unification studies at [[Inje University]], commenting on the offer: "It is unprecedented in the history of inter-Korean relations for North Korea to propose sending an investigation team in response to an issue that has been deemed a 'military provocation by North Korea,'"and thus "The ''Cheonan'' situation has entered a new phase."{{cite web|url=http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/421857.html|title=N. Korea's reinvestigation proposal alters ''Cheonan'' situation|publisher=|accessdate=30 October 2014}} North Korea also warned of a wide range of hostile reactions to any move by South Korea to hold it accountable for the sinking.
If the South puppet group comes out with 'response' and 'retaliation', we will respond strongly with ruthless punishment including the total shutdown of North-South ties, abrogation of the North-South agreement on non-aggression and abolition of all North-South cooperation projects.{{cite web|author=Miyoung Kim|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/world/asia/3725039/North-Korea-declares-phase-of-war-with-south|title=North Korea declares phase of war with south|publisher=Reuters|date=21 May 2010|accessdate=22 May 2010}}
On 24 May, new reports indicated Kim Jong-il had ordered the armed forces of North Korea to be ready for combat a week before.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia-pacific/2010/05/201052534421773321.html|title=Asia-Pacific – S Korea resumes border broadcasts|publisher=Al Jazeera English|accessdate=25 May 2010}} The next day, North Korea released a list of measures that it will take in response to South Korea's sanctions. This would include the cutting of all ties and communications, except for the [[Kaesong Industrial Region|Kaesong industrial complex]]. They would revert to a wartime footing in regard to South Korea and disallow any South Korean ships or aircraft to enter the territory of North Korea.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE64O3YU20100525|title=Text from North Korea statement|publisher=Reuters|date=25 May 2010|accessdate=26 May 2010|first=Jonathan|last=Thatcher}} On 27 May, North Korea announced that it would scrap an agreement aimed at preventing accidental naval clashes with South Korea. It also announced that any South Korean vessel found crossing the disputed maritime border would be immediately attacked.{{cite news|author=BBC|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia_pacific/10170019.stm| title=North Korea scraps South Korea military safeguard pact|publisher=BBC|accessdate=27 May 2010|date=27 May 2010}} On 28 May, KCNA stated that "it is the United States that is behind the case of ''Cheonan''. The investigation was steered by the U.S. from its very outset." It also accused the United States of manipulating the investigation and named the administration of US President [[Barack Obama]] directly of using the case for "escalating instability in the Asia-Pacific region, containing big powers and emerging unchallenged in the region."[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-05/28/c_13321709.htm DPRK accuses U.S. of cooking up, manipulating "Cheonan case"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303170832/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-05/28/c_13321709.htm |date=3 March 2016 }}, by Xiong Tong, Xinhua News Agency, 28 May 2010 On 29 May, North Korea warned the United Nations to be wary of evidence presented in the international investigation, likening the case to the claims of weapons of mass destruction that the United States used to justify its [[2003 invasion of Iraq|war against Iraq]] in 2003 and stated that "the U.S. is seriously mistaken if it thinks it can occupy the Korean Peninsula just as it did Iraq with sheer lies." The North Korea foreign minister warned the [[United Nations Security Council]] of risks of being "misused". It also accused the United States of joining South Korea in putting "China into an awkward position and keep hold on Japan and South Korea as its servants." High ranking North Korean military officials denounced the international investigation and said North Korea does not have the type of submarines that supposedly carried out the attack. They also dismissed claims regarding writings on the torpedo and clarified that "when we put serial numbers on weapons, we engrave them with machines." South Korea's [[Yonhap News Agency]] quoted South Korean officials as saying that North Korea has about ten of the {{sclass-|Yeono|submarines}}. On 2 November, KCNA published a detailed rebuttal of the South Korean joint investigative team report.{{cite news |url=http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2010/201011/news02/20101102-10ee.html |title="Cheonan" Case Termed Most Hideous Conspiratorial Farce in History |newspaper=KCNA |date=2 November 2010 |accessdate=5 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131101123810/http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2010/201011/news02/20101102-10ee.html |archivedate=1 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }} The ''[[Rodong Sinmun]]'' claimed that the "probability of a torpedo attack on (the) Cheonan Warship" was 0%.{{cite web|url=http://www.rodong.rep.kp/InterEn/index.php?strPageID=SF01_02_01&newsID=2012-06-28-0011|title=Probability of Torpedo Attack on Cheonan Warship: 0%|publisher=''[[Rodong Sinmun]]''|author=Ri Song Ho|work=rodong.rep.kp|date=28 June 2012|accessdate=29 June 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130218214048/http://www.rodong.rep.kp/InterEn/index.php?strPageID=SF01_02_01&newsID=2012-06-28-0011|archivedate=18 February 2013|df=dmy-all}} ===International=== {{Main article|Reactions to the 2010 ROKS Cheonan sinking}} When the official report on the sinking was released on 20 May there was widespread international condemnation of North Korea's actions. China was one of few exceptions, simply terming the incident "unfortunate" and "urged stability on the peninsula". This was speculated to be China's concern for instability in the [[Korean Peninsula]]. On 14 June 2010, South Korea presented the results of its investigation to United Nations Security Council members.{{citation|url=http://www.securitycouncilreport.org/atf/cf/%7B65BFCF9B-6D27-4E9C-8CD3-CF6E4FF96FF9%7D/DPRK%20S%202010%20281%20SKorea%20Letter%20and%20Cheonan%20Report.pdf|title=Letter dated 4 June 2010 from the Permanent Representative of the Republic of Korea to the United Nations addressed to the President of the Security Council|work=United Nations Security Council|author=Park In-kook|date=4 June 2010|id=S/2010/281|accessdate=11 July 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.franceonu.org/spip.php?article3753|title=North Korea – Developments at the UN|publisher=Permanent Mission of France to the United Nations|date=July 2010|accessdate=11 July 2010}} In a subsequent meeting with council members North Korea stated that it had nothing to do with the incident.{{citation|url=http://www.securitycouncilreport.org/atf/cf/%7B65BFCF9B-6D27-4E9C-8CD3-CF6E4FF96FF9%7D/NKorea%20S%202010%20294.pdf|title=Letter dated 8 June 2010 from the Permanent Representative of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea to the United Nations addressed to the President of the Security Council|work=United Nations Security Council|author=Sin Son Ho|date=8 June 2010|id=S/2010/294|accessdate=11 July 2010}} On 9 July 2010 the United Nations Security Council made a [[Presidential Statement]] condemning the attack but without identifying the attacker.{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/4208c344-8b6e-11df-ab4d-00144feab49a.html|title=North Korea escapes blame over ship sinking|author=Harvey Morris|date=9 July 2010|work=Financial Times|accessdate=11 July 2010}} China had resisted U.S. calls for a tougher line against North Korea.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/30/world/asia/30korea.html|title=China Returns U.S. Criticism Over Sinking of Korean Ship|author=Andrew Jacobs and David E. Sanger|date=29 June 2010|work=New York Times|accessdate=11 July 2010}} ==Later reports== A member of the North Korean cabinet who defected to the south in 2011 said on 7 December 2012 that the crew of the North Korean submarine which sank ''Cheonan'' had been honored by the North Korean military and government. The defector, known by the alias "Ahn Cheol-nam", stated that the captain, co-captain, engineer, and boatswain of the mini-sub which sank ''Cheonan'' had been awarded "[[Hero of the DPRK]]" in October 2010.''[[JoongAng Ilbo]]'', [http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/northkorea/2012/12/07/31/0401000000AEN20121207008700315F.HTML N. Korean Sailors Awarded Hero's Title For Attack On S. Korean Warship: Defector], 8 December 2012 ==See also== * [[Bombardment of Yeonpyeong]] * [[Korean Air Flight 858]] * [[Korean War]] * [[List of border incidents involving North Korea]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * Van Dyke, Jon M., Mark J. ''Marine Policy'' 27 (2003), 143–158. ==External links== {{Wikinewspar2|South Korean navy ship sinks off North Korean coast|North Korea denies involvement in sinking of South Korean warship|Clinton warns North Korea of "provocative behavior"|US and South Korea to conduct naval exercises in response to warship sinking}} * [https://nordkoreainfo.files.wordpress.com/2010/09/cheonan-report-komplett-1.pdf Joint Investigation Report On the Attack Against the ROKS Ship ''Cheonan''], Ministry of National Defense of the Republic of Korea, September 2010, {{ISBN|978-89-7677-711-9}} * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/nol/shared/bsp/hi/pdfs/20_05_10jigreport.pdf Investigation Result on the Sinking of ROKS ''Cheonan''], Press Summary by The Joint Civilian-Military Investigation Group * [http://mnd-policy.tistory.com/353 South Korean Ministry of Defense "Smoking Gun" Briefing Slides] * [http://www.armscontrolwonk.com/files/MND_slides.pdf Investigation MND briefing slides] * [http://csis.org/files/attachments/100525_AMB_Briefing-2.pdf Briefing – the ''Cheonan'' Situation], Ambassador [[Han Duk-soo]], 25 May 2010 {{Territorial disputes in East, South, and Southeast Asia}} {{Korean War}} {{Coord|37|55|45|N|124|36|02|E|type:event_region:KR|display=title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:ROKS ''Cheonan'' sinking}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Roks Cheonan Sinking}} [[Category:Shipwrecks in the Yellow Sea]] [[Category:2010 disasters in South Korea]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2010]] [[Category:Maritime incidents in 2010]] [[Category:Ships sunk by submarines]] [[Category:Marine salvage operations]] [[Category:North Korea–South Korea relations]] [[Category:Combat incidents]] [[Category:Maritime incidents in South Korea]] [[Category:March 2010 events]]
